At this age it isn’t necessarily soothing for toddlers (like it is for younger babies), but serves instead to drown out external noise. It is particularly useful if there is another sibling in the house, or loud noise emanating from outside. It is inexpensive, easy and portable. Lesson Name: Room Temperature and Dressing Your Baby
Correct Lesson Content:
The ideal room temperature for a baby is between 19-22 degrees. Dressing your baby appropriately is key to ensuring a good night’s sleep and them not waking from being too hot or too cold. Babies commonly wake from being cold as the temperature drops in the early hours of the morning.

What is a tog rating and how does it help you dress your baby appropriately?

A TOG ("Thermal Overall Grade") is a way to measure the insulation and warmth of sleepwear and bedding. The lower the TOG rating, the lighter the fabric. The higher the rating, the more padded it is for warmth and is more suitable to cooler temperatures. When buying sleepwear like swaddles, sleeping bags, sleepsuits, or bedding, look for TOG-rated products. These are most helpful as your baby cannot regulate their temperature like adults can and give you a better guide compared to something being a “winter weight” or “summer weight.”

Keep in mind an adult’s winter duvet is generally rated between 10.5-13.5 TOG and a summer duvet between 2.5-7 TOG.

NOTE: All babies sleep differently just like adults; some run cooler and some hotter. The below table is a guide only, and sometimes trial and error is needed to work out what your baby prefers.

TIP
Does your baby always sleep on their tummy curled up with their legs underneath them? Or wet through their nappies overnight? These are signs your baby might be cold overnight. Try adding another layer or bumping up the room temperature slightly to see if that helps. This is based on anecdotal evidence only and not peer-reviewed research.

It is crucial to make your toddler’s sleep environment as dark as possible. This is to optimise their melatonin production. Melatonin is our sleep hormone and it is produced in the presence of darkness, so any light coming in - can interfere with its production, leading to cat napping and difficulty falling asleep and/or linking sleep cycles. Having a darkened room will also help your toddler be less distracted when they come into a lighter stage of sleep. Shadows and objects around the room are harder to see and your toddler will be more likely to drift back off into another sleep cycle if the room is dark.


Ideally it should be dark enough so that you shouldn’t be able to see your hand in front of your face.


There are many blackout blind options available, both permanent and portable, and window films that are better for oddly shaped windows. Overnight it should be very dark too, so avoid using night lights or lamps at this age (fear of the dark does not usually occur this young, and is more commonly a problem over 2-2.5 years old). If your toddler is having a nap while out in the pram (preferably only their morning nap as we only want them to have a short 20-30 minutes here), using a breathable blackout cover will help reduce external stimulation.​

Red Nose Australia and the American Academy of Paediatrics (AAP) don't promote sleeping in car seats for long periods of time due to the increased risk of SIDS. Babies are top heavy (their head is disproportionately heavier than the rest of them) and when they sit in an upright inclined position like they do in a car seat or capsule it may cause your baby's neck to flex forward or chin down which may block their airway. Never leave a baby asleep unsupervised in a car seat or capsule.​

Lesson Name: Hurdles That Can Wake Your Baby

Correct Lesson Content:
Seldom does a consulting day go by without someone asking my opinion regarding the Snoo. This space-age bassinet was designed by a US paediatrician to simulate settling methods (swaddling, rocking, etc) intended to elongate a baby’s sleep and help them overcome unsettled behaviour. For many sleep-deprived parents, this provides a much-needed respite from frequent feeds and excessive crying. 

Essentially, it’s a robotic night-nanny responding to your baby’s cry volume, rocking and shushing your baby through the night.

Aside from the hefty price tag, there are also fears regarding security, with US embedded-device security firm RedBalloon recently hacking a Snoo via WiFi, to make it shake violently, to highlight security vulnerabilities. Furthermore, although pitched to reduce the incidence of SIDS, the actual SIDS guidelines continue to recommend an empty cot/bassinet with a firm mattress; no gimmicks.Also, although there’s no current evidence for harm regarding radiation exposure, I remain somewhat reluctant to have so much gadgetry around a newborn baby.Finally, and most importantly, the Snoo misses the point.

 Put simply, if your baby needs constant resettling, then there is something being missed that’s causing this unsettled behaviour. 

The key is to identify it, then remedy it. Once this is done, you won’t need any robots to hush your baby through the night.I see countless babies with untreated causes of unsettled behaviour, from colic to eczema, protein intolerance to reflux, and everything in between. I deeply believe that glossing over these treatable conditions does a disservice to babies.Prevention is the key, so yes - babies should/can snooze without SNOOs.******FAQ: What if I’ve already spent a fortune on a SNOO and I’m using it to settle my baby?

If you’ve already purchased a SNOO do not despair - you are not a bad parent, quite the contrary, you’ve invested in something to create an ideal environment for your baby, you’re a FANTASTIC parent! What I want you to be conscious of is monitoring your baby for cues of wind and all the other reasons that could be causing them to be unsettled. The aim is to do our very best to listen to them, to watch them and understand what they are telling us, so that we can help alleviate causes of discomfort.The other aim prior to 6 weeks is to create healthy sleep foundations, in the first 3 weeks of life you can cuddle or rock your baby as they drift off to sleep - don’t worry about negative sleep associations in this period, just enjoy the bonding time.After 3 weeks we want to start creating healthy sleep foundations - e.g. our babies being put down sleepy, but not asleep; allowing them to fall asleep independently. Remember, they are still learning at this point, so if you’re turning the SNOO off or down for even one sleep a day - that’s a terrific start.To recap - you’re a great parent, never forget this! Always look for the cause of the unsettled behaviour so you can prevent it - rather than mask it - and work towards independent settling in time.

FAQ: I’m using the SNOO and I'd like to wean my baby off it, what do you recommend?

At the Dr Golly program we believe weaning off the Snoo bassinet as soon as you can, or even better, avoid using one in the first place. As discussed above SNOO bassinets can mask unsettled behaviour and if your baby needs constant resettling, then there is something being missed. The key is to identify why your baby is unsettled, then remedy it. Once this is done, you won’t need any fancy bassinets to rock your baby through the night.If you are already using a SNOO, then we recommend using the wean function for few days, before using it as a bassinet only, turning off the rocking feature. If your bub has been in the SNOO for a while, then it’s normal to take a little longer to wean off it.

Lesson Name: Moving Baby to their Own Room
Correct Lesson Content:
I’m a proud Red Nose Australia clinical ambassador - The Red Nose Foundation and the American Academy of Paediatrics recommend room sharing (not bed sharing) in their parents' room for the first 6-12 months of life.

This is to decrease the risk of sleep-related deaths often referred to as Sudden Unexplained Death of an Infant (SUDI) and Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS).

The benefits of room sharing:

Room sharing is a protective measure, it allows you to respond rapidly to your baby. It has been shown to be positively associated with the establishment of breastfeeding.

Room sharing Vs bed sharing

Room sharing and bed or surface sharing are very different.

FAQs

Q1: Do Babies Sleep Better in Their Own Room?

ANS: Research has found that after 4 months of age, infants who room shared had more night waking and this resulted in less overnight sleep than those in their own rooms - so overall yes, they sleep better in their own room.

There are a number of reasons for this:

Q2: When should I move my baby into their own room?

ANS: There is no perfect time to move your baby to their own room. After the recommended minimum 6 months, each family needs to make this decision based on what’s right for them and their baby. The research mentioned above looking into room sharing disrupting sleep around 4 months is valid and the desire for uninterrupted sleep needs to be balanced with safety -

In this equation, safety will always trump.

What the study did find was those facing interrupted sleep from room sharing at 4 months, two things arose:

Q3: How to move a baby to their own room?

ANS: If you’re doing this around 6 months, the transition to their own nursery or baby room is much easier and there will be minimal disruption. Younger babies will be less aware of the transition to a separate room and haven’t yet developed object permanence, which makes it easier to put them down and leave their bedroom. Parents are usually a lot more stressed by the move than the baby!

If you’re transitioning with an older baby, the steps below can help.

Step 1: Ensure their own room is set up safely and promotes healthy sleep both day and night.

Step 2: Watch wake windows and if following a routine, make sure it’s age-appropriate to help your baby sleep well in their own room.

Step 3: Have lots of playtime in their own bedroom before using the space for sleep. This is more important for older babies and toddlers, but it will help them see the room as a fun and positive space, not just for sleep.

Step 4: Decide if you’re going to offer both day naps and night sleep in their own room or make it a gradual transition. To start with, you could move their bassinet or use a portacot and do day naps in the nursery for a few days while continuing room sharing overnight before moving all sleeps to their own room.

Step 5: At bedtime, make sure your baby has a relaxing wind-down routine, including some time in their bedroom. This might include a bottle or breastfeed before bed with a story and a cuddle before being placed into their sleeping bag or swaddle and put down to bed.

Q4: Is it ok to offer naps and overnight sleep in different rooms?

ANS: Yes! Many parents are worried this will confuse their baby, but this is usually not the case. It can be a nice transition to start with day naps in their own room while continuing room sharing overnight until you’re more comfortable with the transition.

Babies sleeping in multiple rooms isn’t always possible if you only have one cot; however, using a portacot is a good option.

Q5: Do I Have to Use a Baby Monitor?

ANS: When you have moved your baby to their own room, using a baby monitor can provide an enormous amount of reassurance. There are many different types available, including breathing monitors, video monitors, and audio-only monitors.

Again, depending on where the room is and sleeping arrangements in your house, each family will need to decide which is right for them and their baby. Some smaller homes may be fine with audio-only monitors, while others might want the reassurance of a breathing monitor and the ability to see their baby on a monitor.

Safety

Always follow the Red Nose safe sleep guidelines. Ensure your nursery furniture, including the cot and cot mattress, meets safety requirements and that all heavy furniture is anchored to the wall.

  • Room sharing: is when a baby and parents/caregivers have their own independent sleep space (bassinet, crib, cot) but sleep in the same room.
  • Co-sleeping, or bed sharing: is where both baby and another person will share the same sleeping space, often the parents' bed. Red Nose Australia and The American Academy of Pediatrics recommend babies are always put down in their own sleep space to reduce the risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome.
  • Babies become more aware and sensitive to the world around them as their sleep habits mature.
  • Noises or movement from parents may be more likely to wake them.
  • Another reason is the smell of their mother’s breastmilk - for this reason, I recommend sleeping baby on the dad's or non-breastfeeding parent's side of the bed.
  1. The babies were more likely to be fed back to sleep in the middle of the night: See the lessons on 'night feeds' and 'dropping night feeds' in this program.
  2. Babies were more likely to bed share: Given the safety concerns of bed-sharing - or if night waking is leading to unsafe sleep practices and increasing the risk of fatal sleeping accidents, then moving your baby to a room close by or with a monitor where you can hear/see them may be safer for your family.

Q: My toddler keeps undoing the zip on their sleep-suit/sleeping bag. How can I keep it on them to keep them warm overnight?ANS: Try putting the sleep suit/sleeping back on backwards so they can't reach the zip. Another option is to put a t-shirt on over the top to stop them taking the sleeping bag off.

Q: My toddler is climbing out of the cot and we want to transition to a big bed for safety. Is this ok to do at this age?
ANS: I recommend keeping your toddler in a cot until closer to 2.5-3 years old if possible. This is because they don't develop impulse control until closer to 2.5 years old, so don't understand how to physically stay in their bed all night. This often leads to lots of visits to their parents' bedroom overnight. If it's becoming a safety issue, try taking the base off the cot and putting the mattress on the floor (with the cot sides still assembled). This makes it taller and harder to climb out. Also try to keep them in a sleeping bag to a) keep them warm and b) make it harder to climb out of the cot.

​Video description: The most important of all the settling techniques is the swaddle. In this video Dr Golly will explain the science behind the success of the swaddle, how to choose the right swaddle for your baby, important tricks to achieve the ultimate wrap - and a couple of mistakes to avoid along the way.​

Lesson Name: How to do a Traditional Wrap
Correct Lesson Content:
Step 1: Use a large muslin wrap or stretch jersey wrap. The bigger, the better, and the stretchy material makes it easier to make the wrap firmer. Lay it flat in a square shape.

Step 2: Take your baby and lie them in the middle of the wrap with their head above the material.

Step 3: Bring one arm across their body so it sits above their belly button.

Step 4: Wrap that side of the material across their folded arm and tuck it firmly underneath the other side of their body.

Step 5: Bring their other arm across their body so both arms are folded above their belly button.

Step 6: Wrap the other side of the material over them and tuck it firmly underneath their body.

Step 7: Open the bottom part of the wrap so it makes a triangle shape.


Step 8: Bring it up over your baby and tuck it loosely around their body, ensuring the material doesn’t come above their chest.Remember: firm over the shoulders, loose over the hips.

Lesson Name: Ho to do an Angel Wrap
Correct Lesson Content:
This wrap is great for babies who prefer to have their hands up next to their face and for older babies who like to suck to soothe themselves.

Step 1: Just like a traditional wrap, use a large muslin wrap or stretch jersey wrap. The bigger, the better, and the stretch material can make it easier to make the wrap firmer. Lay it flat in a square shape.

Step 2: Fold about 10 cm of material over at the top of the wrap.

Step 3: Take your baby and lie them in the middle of the wrap with their head above the material.

Step 4: Take one of your baby’s arms and bring it up next to their shoulder, tucking their hand up under the folded part of the material.

Step 5: Bring that side of the material across their body and tuck it underneath the other side of them.

Step 6: Repeat on the other side with the other arm.

Step 7: Wrap the other side of the material over them and tuck it in firmly underneath their body.

Step 8: Open the bottom part of the wrap so it makes a triangle shape.

Step 9: Bring it up over your baby and tuck it loosely around their body, ensuring the material doesn’t come above their chest.

Remember: firm over the shoulders, loose over the hips.

The hip joint is a ball-and-socket joint that allows an incredible range of movements without much risk of dislocation (unlike the shoulder). The socket (pelvic bone, called the acetabulum) is very shallow, not holding the ball tightly. This is how all babies are born. The socket matures over time, and most babies develop a stable hip joint without any intervention.

1 in 6 newborns have some hip instability – incorrect swaddling techniques can increase the risk of Hip Dysplasia.

See the next section on the Dos and Don'ts for swaddling.

What is Hip Dysplasia?

Hip dysplasia is a common condition that occurs when the ball and socket of the hip do not fit together in their normal position. If the socket fails to mature properly and remains shallow, the hip joint is left vulnerable, increasing the risk of early-onset arthritis. In fact, it is the most common cause of hip arthritis in adults.

Early diagnosis of Hip Dysplasia optimizes treatment outcomes.

Risk Factors Include:

  • Female (Hip Dysplasia affects girls more than boys)
  • Firstborn
  • Family history of hip dysplasia (in a first-degree relative)
  • Breech lie
  • Neuromuscular or connective tissue disorder associated with DDH
  • Inappropriate swaddling

Hip Dysplasia isn’t always present at birth, hence the name Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH).

Signs and Symptoms of Hip Dysplasia:

  • ‘Clunk’ or ‘Click’ when moving the hip
  • Uneven thigh creases
  • Crooked buttock creases
  • Leg(s) difficult to spread apart
  • Weight off to one side when sitting
  • Different leg lengths
  • Avoiding weight-bearing
  • Walking on tippy toes on one side
  • Limping when walking
  • Torticollis, Plagiocephaly, and Metatarsus adductus

Every Child’s Hips Need Checking At:

  • Birth
  • 1-4 Weeks
  • 6-8 Weeks
  • 6-9 Months
  • 12 Months
  • Then at normal health reviews until 3.5 years

Your doctor will examine the hips and determine whether an ultrasound is needed to measure hip maturity and guide you accordingly.

The best resource for all information regarding Hip Dysplasia is Healthy Hips Australia:
Healthy Hips Australia

Swaddling the legs can impede proper hip development and may lead to hip dysplasia. Incorrect swaddling techniques can increase this risk. It is important to swaddle the arms while allowing the legs to ‘flop open’ to encourage natural hip maturation.

See below the Dos and Don'ts when swaddling your baby:

DOs

  • Position your baby with their hips bent and knees apart in a frog position.
  • Allow room from the waist down for free leg movement (a triangle shape, not a sausage shape, is a good guide).
  • Swaddle the upper body firmly, but not too tightly.
  • Consider swaddling the arms only.
  • Follow SIDS guidelines.
  • Stop swaddling once your baby starts rolling.

DON’Ts

  • Swaddle legs tightly or press them straight down together.
  • Use sleep sacks and pouches that are snug around the thighs.

Why is this important?

  • Research indicates that inappropriate swaddling can increase the risk of Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH).

Certain swaddle brands and swaddle methods can impact your baby's sleep, particularly swaddles that position your baby in an "arms up" position. While some babies are calmed by this method, it can encourage others to bring their hands to their mouth or brush the side of their face or cheek, which stimulates the rooting reflex.

A baby's rooting reflex is triggered when something brushes their mouth or cheek, causing them to turn their head in search of food. This can wake a baby from a light stage of sleep and make it difficult to resettle without offering milk.

If this sounds like your baby, we encourage you to try an arms across/arms down swaddle for a few days to see if it helps. You may need to persist for a few days until your baby gets used to the new swaddle.

Try not to give up too soon!

Swaddling helps turn on your baby’s calming reflex and protects them from the startle reflex, so un-swaddling too soon can cause an increase in sleep disturbances. There are no strict guidelines as to when you should unswaddle your baby, and many babies will wriggle free of their swaddle independently. All babies should be unswaddled by 6 months, or earlier if they have begun rolling from back to front. Once rolling, it makes it unsafe to continue swaddling them. 30% of babies are un-swaddled by 4 months, 50% by 6 months and 20% need to be un-swaddled in the 6th month for their safety.

Tips on weaning from the swaddle:

  • There are many transitional swaddles available that help make the process easier. This means you might be able to do one arm free at a time.
  • Start with just one arm out for day naps first.
  • If baby wakes after 1 sleep cycle try rolling them onto their side which gently holds their arm down for them and resettle them. Once asleep, be sure to turn them to their back.
  • Once baby is sleeping well during the day with one arm out, try one arm out overnight.
  • Give baby a few days of one arm out during the day and overnight then begin to try both arms out for day and night-time sleep.
  • Once both arms are out you can begin putting baby in a sleeping bag (appropriately TOG rated for the season).
  • The third nap of the day is the hardest to achieve so if you have to keep swaddling for this nap for a little while longer that’s ok.
  • On the arm/arms that are out, if your baby is unsettled then try popping some socks or mittens on their hands as they are used to the familiar feeling of material on their hands.
  • Once unswaddled, if your baby wakes up on their tummy and is upset, firstly try to resettle while they’re still on their tummy with your chosen settling technique and your sleepy words. They’ll soon learn to resettle themselves in this position and it’s ok to sleep like this, as long as they got themselves into that position. If they won’t resettle though, it’s ok to turn them onto their back, but do keep trying to encourage them to resettle on their tummy.

Remember, ALWAYS PUT YOUR BABY DOWN IN THE COT ON THEIR BACK.

FAQ

Once my baby has their arms out do I need to keep rolling them onto their back when sleeping?

Once your baby is sleeping with their arms out whether you roll them back onto their back depends if they can roll front to back:
a) Once your baby can roll confidently from front to back, continue to settle them on their back, but allow them to find their own natural sleeping position if they are able to roll in both directions, it is not necessary to wake during the night to turn them over to the back position.
b) If they can't roll from front to back it's advisable to turn them over.

Just be mindful that rolling onto their stomach can often be a sign they are cold so to double check the temperature of the room and the TOG of their outfit.

Red Nose steps to follow when baby starts to roll on to their tummy or side

  • If you are using a bassinet, it is time to transfer baby into a cot as soon as they first show signs of being able to roll.
  • Give baby extra tummy time to play, this helps baby to develop stronger neck and upper body muscles which enables them to roll back over. It’s best to start giving baby supervised tummy time from birth.
  • Consider using a safe baby sleeping bag as these may delay rolling.
  • Firmly tucked blankets can also help - make sure you follow safe sleep guidelines and have your baby's feet at the end of the bed.

For more information see the rednose.org.au guidelines.

One of the most under-appreciated aspects of raising a newborn is the importance of adequate winding (burping your baby). Through three different videos here, Dr. Golly explains the reasons why wind gets trapped, the ramifications of this, and most importantly, a step-by-step technique to wind your baby effectively.

Video Description: There is no way to stop a baby from swallowing air while they feed (aerophagia). This trapped wind causes a number of problems, both during the feed and in the hours following. In this video, Dr Golly explains exactly how wind causes many of the signs of an unsettled baby, leading to frequent feeding and poor sleep. Ensuring that a baby is well winded (burped) by the end of a feed is crucial to ensuring your baby is settled and in an ideal feeding and sleeping rhythm.

Video Description: This is the single most important part of the entire program. By this stage, you will have a deeper understanding of the implications of trapped wind and here I’ll teach you how to get the wind out - in the form of more burping. This lays the foundation for that ideal routine and a happy, settled, sleeping family.

HICCOUGHS are a very very strong sign that your baby is telling you that they’ve got trapped wind.
Babies will HICCOUGH—it’s normal—just like we do (every now and then)… and a lot of mums will tell you their baby HICCOUGHED a lot in the womb… so don’t be distressed by them.

BUT if your baby:
✅ Hiccoughs A LOT
✅ Grunts a lot
✅ And feeds frequently

These are very very strong signs that they need to be burped more and perhaps you need a more active winding method.

FAQS on HICCOUGHS

➡️ What if my baby starts hiccoughing as soon as I lie them down to burp them?
ANS: If your baby starts HICCOUGHING as soon as you start to burp them, it’s just an indication you need to do a really thorough burping that round. They shouldn’t interrupt the winding method.

➡️ Do HICCOUGHS expel trapped air, do they count as a burp?
ANS: Unfortunately, while it feels like there is a lot of air coming up, it doesn’t count as a burp—again, it just means you have to burp more.

➡️ How do I avoid hiccoughs in the first place?
ANS: No way at all, unfortunately. Babies are obligate nose breathers, so sometimes air just gets in. It doesn’t mean you’re doing anything wrong; it just means you have to help them get the air up.

Q. How do I manage burping when my baby is pulling off frequently?ANS: The most common reason a baby pulls off after a few short sucks is due to the gastro-colic reflex, as highlighted in the program. Trapped wind from the previous feed causes cramping in the colon as soon as the stomach starts to fill with milk from the current feed. While you may need to offer a quick burp each time they fall off the breast/bottle, it’s important to understand that your baby is telling us they needed to burp more at the previous feed. Hopefully, when they are fully winded at this feed, you’ll enter into a nice rhythm/cycle and see them sucking for longer periods of time at future feeds, so this becomes less of a problem.

Q. Do I burp after each boob/bottle suck?
ANS: Yes, it’s important to offer a burp after each side or break during a bottle feed. The goal is to get up as much wind as possible to prevent unsettledness in the coming hours. You don’t have to offer the full 15 minutes of winding after each small break, but at least offer the full 15 minutes at the end of the feed.

Q. When are babies able to burp themselves and the winding process isn’t a thing anymore?
ANS: This can last for many months, but babies slowly get better at winding themselves the longer they spend upright. Also, as they take larger volumes of solids, the need for winding subsides.

Q. Is there a certain number of burps we should be aiming for in a feeding session?
ANS: There's no magic number of burps as some are larger than others. That's why I like to devote a certain period of time to winding.

Q. Do certain foods make breastfed babies more gassy?
ANS: They certainly do! Things that make us gassy will also make babies gassy, like broccoli or beans. Babies also sometimes struggle with spice, garlic, or onion.

Q. We only get a maximum of 1-2 burps per 15 minutes. If this happens in the first 5-10 minutes, can we stop there or still need to continue for the full 15?
ANS: Yes, always respond to your baby. If they bring up all their wind in the first five minutes, then there's no need to continue winding for another ten minutes.

Q. How important is the 2 minutes down, 1 minute up?
ANS: Similar to the question above, always respond to your baby. If you are achieving great burps with, say, 1 minute down and 30 seconds up, and your baby is showing no signs of discomfort from trapped wind, then that’s great. If you’re struggling to get burps up, then the 2 minutes down, 1 minute up for 15 minutes is really important.

Q. Should the burp sound be loud & obvious?
ANS: Your baby’s burps can be loud like Homer Simpson or a small whimper. All are bringing up air but definitely not the same amount. It’s important to wind thoroughly using the active winding technique and to always try to read your baby for signs of trapped wind. Remember, these may not be immediate, and you’ll often see the associated unsettledness in the hours to come.

Q. Is a little spew/spit-up classed as a “burp”?
ANS: Yes, sometimes a big bubble of gas can carry a small posset above it. This is no problem (other than the mess!).

Q. The active winding method requires baby to be horizontal, but my baby squirms and cries when horizontal after a feed, then when picked up has vomited. Is there an alternative to having the baby lay fully flat horizontal?
ANS: You can keep your baby upright for a few minutes before beginning the method. When flat, try cycling the legs, rubbing the tummy, interacting playfully, or using a dummy to try to get them as calm as possible. Remember, small possets don't matter as long as the baby is gaining good weight.

Q. My baby is so hard to burp. I'm lucky to get one in 15 minutes. It's making night wakings so much longer, and I'm exhausted. Any advice?
ANS: Some babies are certainly harder to wind than others. If your active winding technique is right and you're devoting time to it after every feed but still not getting more burps after a week, consider adding a colic mix to help the wind out more easily.

Q. What colic mix do you recommend?
ANS: As a paediatrician, I remain brand-agnostic when it comes to medicines, homeopathics, and listed pharmaceuticals. There are a number of different products on the market, including simethicone, dicyclomine, belladonna, hyoscyamine, and dozens more. It’s important to discuss these with your child’s doctor or paediatrician before administering any due to potential side effects.

Q. Can nipple shields increase the amount of air my baby swallows and make them more uncomfortable?
ANS: No, if your baby is attaching correctly around the shield, this should not be any different from a bottle or a breastfed baby. That is, they will all take in some air, and burping them after every sucking period is essential. I always recommend hand-expressing some milk into the top of the shield so that the first mouthful is milk, not air.

Q. Can I burp a sleeping baby?
ANS: I’m so glad you asked – the answer is YES! Many parents, particularly in the first 6 weeks, find their baby is showing tired signs before they have finished their active winding periods, and they know there are still a burp or two more to get up. My advice here is to swaddle them up, get them into the cot lying flat, and if they are dozy or fully asleep, you can still pick them up gently after a couple of minutes and get that last burp out. I often did the late-night 10/11 pm feed. I’d put them down, go clean my teeth, and then come back to get that last burp—it’s so satisfying!

Q. Is the cot mattress too soft to use the active winding technique?
ANS: For the full active winding method, the cot mattress isn’t ideal. But if it’s just for the last burp as your baby drifts off to sleep, then it’s absolutely fine.

Q. Why do I have to lay my baby down on a hard surface during the Active Winding technique?
ANS: Laying your baby on a hard surface (e.g., carpeted floor, firm change mat) will help your baby's back muscles relax, which in turn allows their abdominal muscles to relax, encouraging wind to come up.

Q. My baby is very upset during the 2 minutes down on the mat. Is it okay to use a dummy/pacifier to help soothe them during this time?
ANS: Yes, it is okay to use a dummy during the 2 minutes of horizontal time while winding to help keep your baby calm. However, remove the dummy before bringing them up to the vertical position. Every few days, try without the dummy during winding to see how your baby goes.

Babies' awake times slowly increase with age. However, at any particular age, one baby might only be able to cope with 1.5 hours of awake time, while another might manage 1 hour and 45 minutes—it’s quite variable. This is why it’s so important to not just watch the clock but also observe your baby and look for those all-important tired signs.

Note: If your baby only had a short cat nap, they likely won’t be able to stay awake as long as they would after a restorative 1.5–2 hour nap. Below are general guidelines for when your baby might begin to show tired signs. Once they do, it’s essential to get them down to sleep within 10–15 minutes to avoid overtiredness.

If your baby is waking after one sleep cycle (40–45 minutes), it might be time to extend their awake time slightly.

This doesn’t mean adding a full 30 minutes at once—start with an extra 5–15 minutes and see how they respond.

A wake-up after only 20 minutes into a nap is often a sign of overtiredness. If this happens, try shortening their awake time slightly.

TIP: In the 1.6 routine lesson, you'll notice that the suggested awake times don’t always align exactly with nap times. This is because awake times are just a guide.

For example, if your 6-week-old wakes at 7 AM and shows tired signs after 1 hour 15 minutes, start the wind-down routine:

  • Take them to their sleep space
  • Brief wind-down (e.g., nappy change, swaddle, turn off lights, white noise on)
  • Gentle rocking/cuddling until drowsy
  • Put them down

This process may take 5–10 minutes, bringing their total awake time to 1 hour 20–25 minutes, which is closer to the suggested 8:30 AM nap time.

Always remember to watch your baby, not the clock—if they need to nap 10–15 minutes earlier or later, that’s completely fine!

Overtiredness in Pre-schoolers 2-5 years old is really common, particularly when they first start to drop their day nap. Here are some overall tips for managing overtiredness with this age group.

Dropping the day nap:

  • When they first start to drop their day nap, consider a day nap every second or third day to start with. It doesn’t have to be an all-or-nothing approach.
  • Ensure some quiet rest time on no nap days, and an earlier bedtime.
  • Ideas for quiet time include watching some television (educational), colouring or drawing, reading books, etc.

Bedtime battles:
Toddlers will often start wanting some control and independence over their day, including bedtime. Follow our CALM technique to help bedtime remain calm for everyone.

Attending childcare or starting kindergarten:
Their days will be busy and exciting, both physically and emotionally. Stretching out their bedtime is the worst thing you can do. On kinder or childcare days, bring bedtime earlier if your preschooler is tired and cranky, or hasn’t slept as well as they usually would in the home environment.

Lesson Name: Tips for Keeping Your Baby Awake During Feeds
Correct Lesson Content:
Is your baby falling asleep while feeding?

While it is very normal, it can also be frustrating and difficult to keep your baby awake during a feed in those first few weeks of life. Often, they’re so comfortable, warm, and tired from feeding that falling asleep is inevitable.

To help keep your newborn awake during a feed:

  • Strip your baby down to just their nappy and do skin-to-skin contact. This helps stimulate the natural instinct to find the breast and feed.
  • Stimulate your baby gently during the feed by tickling their feet, stroking their back, or blowing on their face.
  • Keep a damp, cool face-washer next to you and gently dab your baby’s forehead if they begin to fall asleep.
  • Compress your breasts to help stimulate the flow of milk when it has slowed down, preventing your baby from getting too sleepy.
  • Watch your baby for early feeding cues and feed before they exhibit late cues (distressed crying), as they may be too exhausted to sustain a long feed.
  • Offer a burp—trapped air can make your baby think they are full, so relieving this can allow them to feed longer.
  • Change feeding positions to help wake them up if they start getting sleepy.
  • During the day, feed in a brightly lit room, and don’t hesitate to turn on the TV or play some music.

Lesson Name: Tips for Stretching Your Baby’s Awake Times
Correct Lesson Content:
Stretching your baby's wake windows can be difficult, and sometimes no matter what you try, they just won’t be able to keep their little eyes open. The best way to stretch their wake window is to do it gradually, by adding just 10 minutes to each awake period every few days.

The last awake period of the day may not be able to be stretched, and this can be normal. Babies will be at their most tired towards the end of the day, just like adults, and the worst thing to do here is stretch them too much and create overtiredness before bedtime. Our awake times in this program are just a guide—remember that every baby is different, and your baby might cope well with slightly shorter or longer awake times than what is recommended.

Tips to help extend your baby's awake times:

Tip 1: Face-to-face time with a song or nursery rhyme.

Tip 2: Playtime in a different room—if your baby has been playing in one room, taking them to a different room for the last little bit of their awake time can distract them with a change of scenery.

Tip 3: Taking them outside in the fresh air to look at the trees and environment around them—a burst of sunshine before a nap also helps with melatonin production!

Tip 4: A brief walk in the pram—be careful your baby doesn’t fall asleep here if you’re wanting them to stay awake and go to sleep in their cot/bassinet. The morning nap and the third nap of the day are great ones to have while out and about.

Tip 5: Offering a small top-up feed before their nap.

Q: My baby can only last a short awake time (not the program's recommended awake time). Is this okay?

ANS: Every baby is different, so if your baby is only managing shorter awake times but sleeping well and there are no issues, then there is no problem. However, if your baby is catnapping and very difficult to resettle after one sleep cycle of 40-45 minutes, then this is a sign to try to stretch them a little more and increase their sleep debt. This will help them go back to sleep and transition through sleep cycles without waking fully. You don’t have to stretch them to the recommended times all in one day—simply try extending their awake time by 5-10 minutes every couple of days.

Q: My baby is only having around 1 hour 15 minutes - 1 hour 45 minutes of awake time, but the routine suggests stretching awake time between the last nap and bedtime to 2 hours 15 minutes. Is this correct?

ANS: We don’t recommend stretching your baby if they can’t yet make this awake time, and the times in the routines are a rough guide. To help keep the early evening on track, you could offer a 1-hour late afternoon nap until 5 pm and then bring bedtime earlier as needed. It’s never a good idea to stretch your baby too much and make them overtired, especially at the end of the day. Remember to watch your baby, not just the clock. As your baby gets closer to 12 weeks old, having a longer awake time will be easier, but they still may not reach those exact times suggested in the routine.

Babies thrive on routine, and most parents find it helpful too, knowing how their day will look and when they can schedule appointments or catch up with friends, etc.

Having your baby on an age-appropriate routine is the key to them learning to link their sleep cycles and settle well at sleep time. Routines are not only helpful for parents, but babies thrive when they are settled into a predictable, developmentally-appropriate routine. This minimises the risk of babies becoming overtired, too hungry to feed properly, and stressed.

The routines below are intended to be used as a guide, as some babies will require more or less sleep than the hours described.

As your toddler gets closer to 2 years old, their sleep patterns are almost adult-like and they are only having around 2 hours overnight spent in REM sleep.


Nobody sleeps deeply through the entire night and all children and adults will have partial arousals without even realising it.These are times in which we are in lighter sleep and mumble, toss or turn in bed and seem more awake, but have the ability to put ourselves back to sleep. Lesson Name: Tips for Starting a Routine at 6 Weeks Old
Correct Lesson Content:
Starting a routine can be exciting and daunting at the same time! Some babies will take to a routine on day 1, others may take a couple of weeks.


Here are my TOP TIPS for starting routines at 6 weeks.


TIP 1: As well as being 6 weeks I like babies to be a solid 5-6kg 

- This means they're are nice and robust and ready to take on the longer stretches of sleep between feeds

- If your baby was premature you need to adjust the sleep routines for age correction for the first 6 months

- If your baby isn't 5kg yet then you can continue a second feed overnight around 3-4am to help increase their calorie intake. Your baby might want to feed more frequently during the day and this is perfectly fine. Just try again when your baby is closer to 5-6kg. 


TIP 2: Don't be militant - your baby and you are still learning

- It's great to follow a routine, babies thrive with consistency

- But everyday can still be a bit different and that's ok

- Be kind to yourself and don't stress if your baby takes a while to settle into a routine


TIP 3: Think long term

- The work you did in the first 4 to 6 weeks and the work you are doing now are all working towards overall healthy sleep habits ...which over the months and years ahead will help them learn to love their sleep! 

- Think of this as laying the foundations of great sleep for life


TIP 4: Awake windows may need to stretch

- At 6 weeks old your baby may not be able to quite handle the 1 hour and 30 minutes awake time to match the routines, that's OK

- You can gradually stretch them out by adding 5-10mins to their awake time every few days until they're able to last 1 hour and 30 minutes. 


TIP 5: Re-settling and assisted naps may be needed

- If your baby doesn't sleep for the entire recommended nap length then

a)  resettle them with your resettling technique (I go through this in module 1.8 Settling & Calming Babies) or 

b) continue the nap as an assisted nap (in the pram, carrier or on you) - there's an entire section on this at the bottom of this 1.6 Routines Module - HINT... I'm a huge fan of the carrier for these times.


TIP 6: Filling in time before a feed

- If your baby wakes after a nap and it isn't yet time for a feed, if they are happy enough then give them some play time on the mat or go for a brief walk until it's closer to the suggested feed time

- If you're using assisted naps this isn't often a problem  


TIP 7: Extra naps and power naps

- Sometimes they may wake and not be able to be resettled, just do your best and know that it's ok to offer an extra nap and/or an extra feed. 

- Once your baby is 12 weeks old we can use power naps to help keep the day on track (see the Power Naps lesson further on in the program).


TIP 8: Everyday is a fresh start

- Not every day is perfect - not every feed is perfect - not every sleep is perfect - and that's OK, that's life

- Stay flexible, have a plan if your baby wakes early and don't take it personally or think it's reflection of your parenting, your baby is still learning and every new day is the perfect day to try again

Routine is so important in a baby’s world!

It gives them predictability and an expectation of how their day will look, and this means nap time and bedtime is something they grow to love and look forward to. I’ve worked with hundreds of babies and helped them learn to love their sleep and as they grow older see them reach out for their cots in anticipation of peaceful sleep.

TIP: It's so important to wake your baby from their naps if they are having longer than mentioned in the routines below. Our goal is to protect overnight sleep and also encourage the lunchtime nap to be the longest of the day, so waking them from their morning nap is the best thing to help this!

​NOTE: THE PRINTABLE ROUTINE ONLY CONTAINS OPTION 1. You are still more than welcome to adjust this and use option 2 if this works best for your family and your baby.​

​What does the ‘perfect feed’ look like?
One breast (or part of bottle), followed by 15 minutes of active burping. Then the second side (or remainder of bottle), followed by another 15 minutes of active burping. During active burping, there are times for diaper changes, development-enhancing games (play with rattles and toys that make noise, read books, sing nursery rhymes), tummy-time, etc.​

Babies are generally less active during night feeds and therefore may swallow less air. The winding requirement does NOT disappear overnight though! If you’re getting 6 burps during a day feed, you might only get 4 overnight, but it is still crucial to get those 4, or at least try for 6.

KEY POINT:You can still burp a sleeping baby, in many ways it is actually easier than when they are awake!

Toddlers and Night Feeding

By this age I expect toddlers 1-2 years of age to be sleeping a full 12 hours through the night 7pm to 7am, and your toddler should be eating 3 meals and a couple of snacks during the day, with milk turning into the supplementary not primary source of nutrition. Toddlers shouldn't be waking overnight from hunger, and milk overnight at this age can lead to less hunger during the day which subsequently causes a negative cycle of feeding overnight. My general guidelines for dropping night feeds are in the Dropping Night Feeds video, much of this process is to do with nutrition and consolidating feeds to the daytime.

For many of you, this may not be as relevant and your toddler could be feeding habitually for comfort. If your toddler is feeding for comfort then it's perfectly ok to drop any night feeds cold turkey and resettle them when they wake overnight using your settling technique (see the next section).

TIP: Often the non-breastfeeding parent (if still breastfeeding) is best to do the resettling overnight.


It can take a couple of tough nights to adjust:

Dropping night feeds isn't as daunting as it sounds. As you'll see in the video, there are gradual ways to do this, however at this age dropping them cold turkey is also perfectly fine as long as your toddler is eating and drinking well during the day. 

It might well be a couple of tough nights until your toddler adjusts to the new normal and learns to sleep through without a feed, but you can be reassured in the fact that your toddler isn't waking from hunger and that they are simply protesting because you're not responding as they are used to.

TIP:  It can be helpful to let your workplace know that you might be a little more tired for a couple of days and explain what you're doing.

A solid night's sleep for all will begin to be the new normal and will be worth the effort!

NOTE: Both roll-over and dream feeds should only be used until 7 months as per the routine.

What is a roll-over feed?

A roll-over feed is suitable for late evening feeds (they work really well for some, not all babies). They involve gently waking your baby, but keeping stimulation to a minimum, like ‘rolling’ one sleep into the next. Lights are kept dim, and there are minimal interactions. While a roll-over feed is likely to be smaller than a full daytime feed, it is far more filling than a dream feed.

What is a dream feed?

A dream feed is a feed where your baby stays asleep or is aroused to a lighter stage of sleep.
These are suitable for babies over 6 weeks old. You may choose to keep the stimulation to a minimum or try to maintain sleep throughout.

Roll-over Vs dream feed?

Both are reasonable options - your baby will tell you which they prefer.

How do I offer a dream feed?

This feed can be offered by both breast and bottle, and if you’re wanting to introduce a bottle into your baby’s routine, this is the perfect time to add it (I recommend this after 4-6 weeks when breastmilk supply has been established).

Step 1: Gently pick up your sleeping baby out of the bassinet or crib.
Step 2: Keep your baby swaddled or in their sleeping bag.
Step 3: Position yourself comfortably as you would for any regular feed.
Step 4: Gently tease your baby’s mouth with the nipple or bottle teat until they open enough to latch.

  • If it’s difficult, try stroking their cheek or lips to stimulate their rooting reflex and encourage them to take the nipple.

Step 5: Give your baby a bottle or breastfeed.

  • Some babies will only take one side of the breast or a smaller amount than they usually would in a bottle compared to a regular feed, and this is normal.

Step 6: Make sure your baby is well winded.

  • Even though it’s a quick feed, it’s important not to miss this. This will help stop them waking in the middle of the night from trapped wind and be likely to sleep longer. You can absolutely burp them while they are asleep/half asleep.

Step 7: After a quick cuddle, put your drowsy baby back to sleep in their crib or bassinet.

Dream feeds don’t work for every baby. Some will wake too much and be difficult to resettle, while others just refuse to feed while still asleep. I recommend continuing to try a dream feed for at least one week, as it can take this long for it to be successful. Dads can offer the dream feed with a bottle while mum goes to bed earlier for the night.

Dream feeds are often much smaller and less satisfying than feeding when awake—and may not give them the calories they need to sleep through until 7am reliably. However, if your baby is sleeping through till morning with a dream feed, there is nothing you need to change!

Dream feeds should not be offered past 7 months old. Disturbing their night sleep at this age can be counterproductive and actually increase night waking, so after 7 months, let your baby wake on their own for a feed overnight if needed.

Tips for a successful roll-over or dream feed

Tip 1: Keep the lights dim and stimulation to a minimum—try to use a hallway light or a small nightlight to help stop your baby waking fully.
Tip 2: Only change their nappy if it is heavy or soiled. If necessary, change the nappy before the feed and only unswaddle their bottom half to try and keep them as drowsy and settled as possible.
Tip 3: If offering a bottle, have it all ready to go so you don't have to leave the room to prepare it.
Tip 4: Leave the white noise playing to help keep your baby calm and quiet.

FAQs on the Late Night Feed

Q:My baby is going down at 7pm and sleeps to 3-4am. I'm hesitant to wake them for the 10pm/11pm roll-over/dream feed. Do I still need to wake them?
A: YES, absolutely. The reason I recommend this late evening feed is because we are aiming to consolidate the nice long stretch overnight and get your baby sleeping as close to 7am as possible. The 3-4am feed is what we are aiming to drop first, followed by the 10/11pm evening feed (once solids are established).

Q:How long should a dream feed be?
A: Let your baby feed for as long as they want to here. It might be 5 to 15 minutes at the breast, or 60-120ml in a bottle. As mentioned above, sometimes this feed isn't a full feeding because your baby is still drowsy or asleep, and this is fine.

Q:Is breast or bottle feeding best here?
A: Babies can be breastfed or bottle-fed with expressed milk or formula at this feed. It's a great feed to offer a bottle at, as it means mum can go to bed earlier and dad or the non-breastfeeding parent can still offer the feed—again taking into consideration that I don't recommend this until breastmilk supply has been established if you're breastfeeding.

Q:How do I know if the dream feed is working for my baby?
A: Dream feeds are supposed to help babies sleep for a longer stretch and be easier to put back down to bed. If this isn't happening and night wakings are continuing frequently despite trying for a week, then it might be best to let your baby wake on their own for a feed, or wake them and feed at 10/11pm instead.

Dream feeds are fantastic, but in my experience, they don't work for all babies, and this is okay.

Please see our lessons on early morning waking in Chapter 1.3 - Routines.

Below is a contingency plan of what to do if your baby wakes early.

Under 5 months old
Power nap: If your baby has woken early (i.e., pre 6.15 am) and will not resettle, then a power nap can be used until 5 months old. A power nap is a small 15-minute nap ONLY to help get your baby through to their next nap time and keep their day on track. Allowing them to only have 15 minutes may seem cruel, but we want to avoid them falling into a very deep sleep, as this will decrease their drive to sleep, making their next nap harder to achieve.

So your morning might look something like this:
6 am - Wake up, unable to be resettled
7.15 am - Power nap
7.30 am - Wake baby up
9 am - Nap 1 back on track.

A power nap is only a temporary solution and should only be used for a few days in a row, as we don’t want it to become a new habit.

Over 5 months old:
If your baby wakes early, try your best to stretch them out until as close to their normal nap time as possible. A little walk around the garden or playtime in a different room might help pass the time if they are more fussy and tired than usual because of the early wake-up.

Double check why your baby might be waking - and think of hunger as the last option.

Could they be overtired or under-tired from the previous day's sleep?

  • Double check the age bracket your baby is in and if their day sleep matches what's in their age-appropriate routine. It can be tempting to let them take extra long naps and have some bonus time to yourself - but most likely this will bite you in the bottom overnight.
  • Don't forget to cap their morning nap at what is age-appropriate. Ie. 45 mins at 6 months, 30 mins by 8 months. Remember, too much sleep at the first nap can encourage early morning waking.
  • Consider dropping them to 2 naps if they are consistently waking early despite eliminating all other reasons.

Are they too cold?

  • In my experience, this is the most common reason a baby wakes around 4am (the coldest part of the night) - double-check what TOG they are wearing and the temperature of the room. If it's not 18-21°C think about a heater option.

Are they too hot?

  • This is less common but still something to think about.

Is the morning light coming in and waking them up?

  • This is a HUGE one, if you haven’t invested in blackout blinds and your baby is waking as the sun comes up, this is probably the reason.

Could it be wind?

  • See my content on Colic and wind signs to dive further into this. Most of the time due to it being the middle of the night we don’t wind as effectively or for as long for evening or night feeds - this can lead to wind and may make them very uncomfortable in the early hours.

Is it a dirty nappy?

  • It seems obvious but have a smell - if there’s a poo you need to change it, I’m yet to meet a baby that will sleep comfortably with a soiled nappy. Most babies will handle a slightly wet nappy but if it’s super full (if they are cold and have been having lots of overnight feeds it probably is) you will need to change this too. Keep the lights low or off and just use the torch on your phone - calm and dark for overnight changes is the key.

Do they have eczema that could be bothering them?

  • Like colic, if they are uncomfortable it will be impossible to get them to sleep - work with your doctor to get on top of any eczema.

And lastly, Are they hungry?
The reason why we look at hunger last is if a baby is fed as soon as they wake before 7am, they take in calories, which means they won't be as hungry or have as full of a feed in the morning …and the cycle of too many calories overnight and not enough during the day continues - this is often referred to as reverse cycling. Revisit the video on dropping night feeds for more on this.

If your baby is hungry in the early hours of the morning and showing signs of readiness for solids then it's an ideal time to start introducing these.

For babies over 6 months old, ensure they're having 25-50g of a protein source at their lunchtime solids. This will help stabilize their blood sugars overnight, help them feel fuller, and encourage them to sleep through the night.

For all early morning waking, keep the lights preferably off or as down low as possible and limit all interaction: this isn't the time to sing songs and chat to them as we want to try and keep them as sleepy as possible - the less stimulation the better.

Remember that early morning waking is the hardest thing to fix when it comes to infant sleep. It can take 3-4 weeks of consistency to see improvements. If your baby starts waking at 6am instead of 5.45am this is a small change, but each small change should be taken as a big win!

Early Morning Waking FAQs

Q. What should I do if my baby wakes before 6am?
ANS: Go through the above checklist and rule out common reasons for waking. Try to resettle your baby using your chosen settling technique (chapter 1.8 - settling and calming babies). If you feel your baby is hungry then feed as needed, but aim to start decreasing this overnight feed. Please refer back to the Dropping Night Feeds video in this lesson.

Q. What should I do if my baby wakes around 6am and won't resettle?
ANS: For babies under 5 months old, try to resettle them but if they don't go back to sleep, use a power nap to help keep the day on track (see more info in the 'Power Naps for Babies Under 5 Months Old' lesson further along in this chapter).

For babies over 5 months old, always try and resettle them until closer to 6.30/7am. If they won't resettle then try to stretch them as close to their first nap time as possible. Try your best to get them close to 9am, as offering a morning nap earlier than this can just encourage the early morning waking.

Lesson Name: Power Naps for Early Morning Waking/Cat-Nappers
Correct Lesson Content:
A power nap is a brief 15-minute nap that helps get your baby through to the next nap time. They're used when your baby has woken early from a nap and not been able to resettle, or if they've woken early in the morning and not resettled back to sleep.

These are useful from 12 weeks old - 5 months old. They are a temporary solution and shouldn’t be used for weeks on end, but are very useful in the short term to help encourage them to adjust to a new routine and keep their day on track.

It’s very important to wake your baby after 15 minutes to stop them from falling into a deep sleep, as otherwise, this will throw off their next nap. Power naps are fine to be assisted naps, so in the car seat, pram, or carrier is perfectly ok.

How you might use a power nap is outlined below, but obviously, the timing will differ for babies depending on their age:

Early morning waking

  • 6:00 am - Baby woke and wouldn't resettle
  • 7:30 am - Power nap
  • 7:45 am - Woken from power nap
  • 8:30 am - Morning nap

Cat nap

  • 9:00 am - Baby down for a nap
  • 9:40 am - Woke up and unable to be resettled
  • 11:00 am - Power nap in pram
  • 11:15 am - Woken from power nap
  • 12:00/12:15 pm - Down for next nap

Your main priority at this age is to avoid overtiredness but still try and teach your baby to consolidate their naps.

Does your baby go to bed in the evening and then wake after 30-45 mins?

It’s like they’re treating bedtime as a nap and seem completely awake after 1 sleep cycle – these are called false starts. False starts happen for a few different reasons and they can be incredibly frustrating for parents, when you think you’ve finally got your baby down for the night.

THE MAIN CAUSES OF FALSE STARTS ARE:

Over-tiredness

  • When your baby is overtired, they go to bed at night with a high level of circulating cortisol, our stress hormone.
  • This makes it harder for them to connect sleep cycles and will often wake before going into a deep sleep and will often wake crying and inconsolable.

Under-tiredness

  • This is when your baby has possibly had too much sleep during the day, or napped too close to bedtime and simply doesn’t have enough sleep pressure (or sleep debt) built up.
  • Try extending their awake time and ensure you’re following an age appropriate routine.

Unable to link sleep cycles yet

  • At this young age it's very normal for your baby to not link their sleep cycles yet, and they may need some assistance from you to help get them back to sleep.
  • Settling techniques like shush-pat, or being rocked, held, or a dummy being replaced.
  • Some babies won't learn to link sleep cycles until closer to 4-5 months.
  • Focus on creating an ideal sleep environment, eliminating hurdles, and sticking to an appropriate wake window/routine.

Inappropriate daytime routine

  • Babies thrive on routine and if they are in a routine that includes too much day sleep, or not enough day sleep, then they’re more likely to experience false starts at bedtime.
  • It’s a good idea to review your baby’s nap times and alter them if you think it could be contributing to overnight sleep.

Sleep environment

  • This is particularly important during those months and locations that have daylight savings time.
  • Make sure your baby’s bedroom is blacked out as much as possible, as too much light coming in can encourage them to wake after 1 sleep cycle before the sun goes down for the day.

The recommended routines will give you a guide as to how your day will look, however, we appreciate that you will still need to get out of the house and sometimes it will be during suggested nap times. It's important to note that after around 6 months of age, sleep on the go (in the pram/carrier/car seat) is usually less restorative and your baby will be more likely to wake after one sleep cycle and be difficult to get back to sleep. Because of this, the naps we suggest you offer while out and about are the first-morning nap and the third late afternoon nap (if your baby hasn't dropped it yet). These naps are great to offer on the go as we are not so focused on their length and it is generally ok if they have a shorter nap at these times. The third late afternoon nap is a tricky one to achieve as your baby reaches 7-8 months so this nap is perfectly fine to have anywhere, in fact, it is usually easier to get babies to have a brief nap in the pram, car, or carrier at this time.

FOCUS: The nap we want to focus on being the longest and most restorative is the lunchtime nap. This is because it helps keep on top of over-tiredness and sets you up for a better night. It is also the nap your baby will be having until they are around 3 years old, so teaching them now to have a longer nap here helps in the long term. As much as you can, offer the lunchtime nap at home in their cot and focus on resettling your baby if they wake early.

**﻿To help your baby sleep while out and about during the day, try to recreate their sleep environment as much as possible:**

  • Darken the pram with a breathable blackout cover. Don't use a blanket as this doesn't usually provide enough darkness and the temperature in the pram can become dangerously high.
  • Use the same white noise or nature sounds that you use at home. There are many portable white noise machines available that run on batteries.
  • If your baby is still swaddled and you want to encourage them to nap in the pram, use the same swaddle you do at home.
  • If you do have to head out during your baby's lunchtime nap then on occasion it is ok to offer a longer morning nap and then 2 shorter naps later in the day, but just try not to make this a regular pattern. You might also notice your baby is more tired at bedtime so don't stretch them out, bring bedtime earlier.

**﻿If you are going out for dinner occasionally we recommend the following changes:**

  • If you are heading out to a restaurant then giving your baby a slightly longer 3rd nap (or a brief catnap if they have already dropped this nap) will allow you to push bedtime out a bit. If your baby falls asleep in the car on the way home then attempt to transfer them to their cot, however, if they wake up this is ok. Offer a small top-up feed and pop them to bed.
  • If you are visiting family or friends and have access to a porta cot then treat your baby's bedtime the same as you usually would (minus the bath if this is too difficult). Try to recreate their usual sleep environment as much as possible. Make sure the room is as dark as possible, use your white noise/nature sounds, use the same swaddle or fitted cot sheet so it smells like home, and bring any comforters/dummies your baby uses at sleep time.

Lesson Name: What To Do If My Baby Wakes Early From a Nap?
Correct Lesson Content:
If your baby wakes early from a nap, then:

  1. Resettle them using your settling technique (I'll talk you through these in section 1.8 Settling & Calming Babies), or
  2. Continue the rest of the nap as an Assisted Nap.

At this age, we want to keep on top of overtiredness, so even if they’ve done the first part of the nap in their cot/bassinet and the rest is assisted, this is okay.

What are assisted naps?

An assisted nap is exactly that—it’s a nap where you assist your baby to sleep. They can be in the:

  1. Pram
  2. Carrier
  3. Being held

Assisted naps are very useful in the age group of 4–16 weeks—helping keep the day on track if they wake early while you're establishing a routine, as well as managing overtiredness. After about 4 months, I don’t recommend relying on these and instead focus on resettling in the cot.

I'm a HUGE fan of assisted carrier naps for little babies who wake early, because:

  • When your baby is close to you, they’ll almost instantly resettle.
  • You have your arms and legs free, so you can still do quite a bit—which is good for both your physical and mental well-being.

Important Safety Notes for Assisted Naps:

Car naps:

Car naps are often considered a type of assisted nap, but Red Nose does not recommend using these. Always monitor a baby sleeping in the car closely due to the risk of breathing issues if their chin is in the wrong position.

Carrier naps:

Always follow the TICKS rules:

  • Tight
  • In view at all times
  • Close enough to kiss
  • Keep their chin off their chest
  • Supported back

Never fall asleep in a chair or lie down with your baby in a carrier.

Being held by you:

The term "nap trapped" is real—when you have a baby sleeping on you, it’s impossible to do much else other than snuggling them. While this can be beautiful occasionally, it can be debilitating long term. I don’t recommend these too often, and it’s essential that you stay awake and alert, as falling asleep is a huge safety risk.

Lesson Name: Should I Wake My Baby From Their Nap?
Correct Lesson Content:
Yes, you can absolutely wake a baby!

Waking your baby:

  • Around the same time each morning, or
  • If they are oversleeping on a particular nap

Waking your baby will help them establish a routine faster and improve overnight sleep, as too much daytime sleep can impact those long stretches overnight.

The morning nap is the nap your baby is most likely to oversleep for, as they will see it as a continuation of overnight sleep. While it’s tempting to let your baby keep sleeping, this may put the whole day out of whack.

How best to wake a sleeping baby?

Whatever sleep you are waking them from, introducing a Happy Wake Up will help your baby learn to distinguish when it is time to go back to sleep and when it is time to wake up.

A Happy Wake Up includes:

  • Quietly entering the room and gently waking your baby up
  • Opening the blinds or turning on a light
  • Gently saying a wake-up greeting

I like to sing a song:
"Good morning, good morning, good morning to you, good morning baby XX-XX, cocka-doodle-do!"

  • Then, make a big fuss with lots of over-the-top praise about what a good sleep they had!

Your baby will learn that quiet, sleepy words in the dark, such as "night night, it's sleep time," mean it’s time to go back to sleep, while a Happy Wake Up with lights means it’s time to get up.

Lesson Name: How To Navigate an Unplanned Nap
Correct Lesson Content:
If your baby falls asleep as you’re walking home in the pram or in the car (these are the most likely scenarios) try and keep them awake and stimulated as much as possible.

  • If there’s a passenger in the car tickle their chin
  • Wind the windows down and let in some fresh air
  • If they are in the pram - have them face you so you can keep them engaged
  • You may look deranged in the front seat or walking along…but if you know you know …sometimes all you need is an extra 5 minutes to get home and you know they’ll sleep the full 2 hours…PLEASE STAY AWAKE LITTLE ONE!!

If they do nod off it’s not the end of the world - at this age it depends on if they're having 1 or 2 naps and what time of the day this unplanned nap happens.

OPTION 1: If the nap happens in the morning and you were trialling them on just a lunchtime nap, let them have a brief 15min morning nap and push the lunchtime nap out by 30-60mins. ie. Your toddler fell asleep unexpectedly at 10.30am. Wake them at 10.45am and offer them a second, longer nap at around 1.30/1.45pm. 


OPTION 2: If your toddler falls asleep unexpectedly in the afternoon (ie. 4pm or later), try to wake them and keep them awake and do an early bedtime, however if they've fallen asleep for a brief time you might need to push bedtime slightly later by 30-45mins.

Q: My child needs to drop their nap but how do I stop them from becoming so tired and cranky by the afternoon?

ANS: It’s normal during any nap transition for there to be an adjustment period and some increased tiredness. With tiredness of course comes cranky and grumpy kids, but if their night sleep is being affected then I still recommend dropping the day nap. Try your best to push them through but after lunch make sure they do have some quiet time. This might be reading stories, doing some quiet drawing or building blocks or even watching a movie. If they are super tired and cranky by dinnertime then bring their evening routine forward. Try dinner at 4.45pm, bath at 5.15pm and bedtime by 6/6.15pm. Push through for a few days and they will quickly adjust to their new routine and be sleeping more soundly at night.

Q: My child is fighting bed-time in the evening. How do I get them to go to sleep earlier?
ANS: If your child is fighting going to bed this is a sign that they are ready to either have their day nap capped back or dropped completely. If they still have a nap of 1hr+ then start capping it back to as little as 30-40mins with a bedtime of 7pm. If bedtime is still an issue with a reduced nap time then drop it completely and bring bedtime a little earlier until they adjust through the transition. Some sleep training may also need to happen if the bedtime battles have been going on for a while. Please see our settling techniques and choose one you feel will suit your child and family and also one you can stay consistent with.

Q: I have to work and can’t get my child into bed early with childcare pick up/dinner/bath routine. How do I go about this?
ANS: You just have to do your best here! Sometimes life throws us crazy days and we can’t always get our children into bed when we’d like to. However on the days you can I recommend aiming for a bedtime as per my routine as a well-rested child is one that will cope better when the schedule is thrown off sometime.

Q: We follow your routine but my child is now crying at bedtime for 20-30mins and taking longer to go to sleep. Is this normal and what can we do to fix it?
ANS: As your child gets older they are better at coping with a longer awake time between the end of their lunchtime nap and bedtime. Usually, it is around 5 - 5.5 hours for a 2 - 3 year old if still having a day nap. If your child has recently started protesting more at bedtime and taking longer to fall asleep it is a sign to extend their awake time here, starting with 15 min increments. However, if they are waking late from their lunchtime nap (ie. around 3pm and needing a 5 - 5.5 hour awake time), the best option is to cut the nap back so they are having a shorter nap/waking earlier and then into bed for the night at an earlier, more age-appropriate time.

Lesson Name: Routine for Babies Who Feed 3 Hourly
Correct Lesson Content:
​

SUGGESTED ROUTINE FOR 6-12 WEEK OLD BABIES WHO ARE FEEDING 3 HOURLY 

For babies who are smaller and not quite 5-6 kg yet, or for babies who are struggling to stretch to 3.5-4 hourly feeds, this is a suggested routine that gives parents and caregivers something to work their day around. Remember however that for babies this age, everyday will look different and it's VERY normal for them to not link sleep cycles yet. Everything you're doing now is helping to teach your baby to love their sleep and setting them up for healthy sleep in the future. 

This routine is based on 3 hourly feeds and 4 naps in the day. Because it includes an extra nap, the length of the naps has been shortened to ensure your baby isn't having too much day sleep, which can then go on to affect night sleep. 

You DO NOT have to follow this routine if you're happy feeding 3 hourly (or on demand) and being aware of your baby's age appropriate awake times and watching their tired signs for nap time. 


7am awake and feed

8.30/8.45am Nap 1 for 1-1.5 hours

10am awake and feed

11.30/11.45am Nap 2 for 1-1.5 hours

1pm awake and feed

2.30/2.45pm Nap 3 for 40-60 mins

3.30/3.45pm awake (if your baby wakes before 4pm then go ahead and have some mat or play time)

4pm feed

5/5.15pm Nap 4 for 40- 60 mins

6pm half feed

6.30pm bath

7pm remaining half feed and bedtime 

Option 2: You don't have to offer half feeds at 6pm, you can get your baby up from the nap at 6pm, offer play time and bath time and then offer a full feed at 6.45/7pm instead.


Over time, you can continue trying to help your baby get to 4 hourly feeds and the suggested 6-12 or 12-16 week routines found earlier in the program.

A circadian rhythm is the body’s natural sleep-wake cycle, lasting 24 hours. The main hormone involved in this process is melatonin. Light drives our melatonin levels down, and darkness allows it to rise. This rise in melatonin is what makes us sleepy and helps us drift off to sleep each night. As light increases in the morning, cortisol begins to circulate, which is like our body’s natural coffee hit, driving wakefulness.

Babies mostly rely on their mother’s circadian rhythm but need to develop their own soon after birth. It is well established by 3 months of age, and there are many things you can do to help this process.

  • Avoid excessive stimulation in the late evening or for any overnight awakenings. Keep feeds quiet, calm and make sure the room is dimly lit - to encourage your baby to learn the difference between night and day. Doing this will also maximise the chances of dropping overnight feeds, instead of long day time sleeps and feeding clusters in the evening.

  • Don’t pick your baby up if they are making sounds/movements but remain asleep. This usually means they’re cycling through non-REM sleep. Babies can be very active and noisy throughout their sleeps, be mindful not to stimulate them awake, when they are capable of returning to deep sleep by themselves.

Deep sleep—or REM (rapid eye movement)—makes up half of a newborn’s total sleep time, but this decreases as they get older, so they are less and less likely to sleep deeply through noises, light, etc.

As those sleep cycles are 40-45 minutes long, it’s more likely that your baby will wake at around that time as they come into lighter sleep.

In The Dr Golly Sleep Program, our aim is to encourage babies to link these 40-50 minute cycles.

It’s really important to manage expectations with what’s achievable here—some babies will learn to link their sleep cycles straight away, while others may take weeks or months to fully master this skill.

Top tips for linking sleep cycles:

TIP 1: Room environment

  • This is where an ideal sleep environment (section 1.1) is crucial.
  • A dark room with white noise played will help your baby fall back asleep and transition through to the next sleep cycle.

TIP 2: Age-appropriate settling technique

  • Using a consistent age-appropriate settling technique will provide appropriate parental expectations and also encourage them to go back to sleep and continue their nap or overnight sleep.

TIP 3: Put asleep in the same spot they wake up

  • Babies should ideally be put down to sleep in the same place they will wake up.
  • Just imagine if we fell asleep somewhere and woke up somewhere completely different—we’d most likely wake suddenly, be frightened, and not be able to settle. Babies are exactly the same.

TIP 4: To bed sleepy, not asleep

  • Make sure you put your baby in their cot/bassinet sleepy but not asleep.
  • We want them to try to settle to sleep by themselves, without needing to be rocked or fed to sleep.

TIP 5: Make sure they have enough sleep pressure

  • Sometimes, babies waking after a single sleep cycle and not being able to resettle could be due to not accumulating enough sleep pressure.
  • Increasing their awake time by 5 to 15 minutes can sometimes be helpful.

TIP 6: Don't put insane amounts of pressure on yourself to achieve this

  • At this age (3-16 weeks), some babies just won't have learned to link their sleep cycles yet.
  • It’s okay to aim for just 1-2 naps a day in the bassinet or cot as we’re only beginning to teach them to learn to love their sleep.

TIP 7: Remove all other hurdles that could be causing them to wake and not re-settle after a cycle

  • There’s a list in section 1.1 of all the common hurdles that can cause a baby to wake.
  • As you're focusing on linking sleep cycles, sometimes it's valuable to print this off and stick it on the fridge so all caregivers are keeping an eye on things that could make your baby uncomfortable. When you're in the thick of sleep deprivation and exhausted from the wake-ups, you can sometimes forget the simple things.
