Step 1: Under 4 months old, resettle your baby for 30 minutes using your settling technique.
Step 2: After 30 minutes, continue the nap any way possible—I often refer to these as "assisted naps."

Assisted naps include using the pram, carrier, car, or holding them.

  • Personally, I’m a massive fan of the carrier/body wrap as your baby will usually go straight back to sleep when they are close to your body PLUS you have your hands free!
  • If they are a "colicky" baby, being upright can often help with the discomfort they are feeling.
  • There’s no right or wrong here—whatever works for you and your baby is best.

Don't despair if your baby isn't linking their sleep cycles yet 🦄

However, we are trying to teach your baby that waking from a sleep doesn’t necessarily mean it's time to be picked up, so encouraging the nap to continue is essential for the learning process.

Lesson Name: Is It OK To Rock Or Hold My Baby To Sleep?
Correct Lesson Content:
There is a very important, very fundamental rule about humans: the way we fall asleep is the way we expect to wake up. It may sound silly, but if you fell asleep in your bed tonight and woke in the middle of the night in the same place, you roll over, go back to sleep—and don’t remember. But if you woke in another room—you would startle awake and look to find out how/why things have changed. Babies are the same. If they fall asleep being rocked in their mother’s arms, then at the end of a sleep cycle, they will wonder where that parent is—and be unable to stitch together multiple cycles. While this can be a lovely way to help your baby fall asleep on occasion, it also isn't sustainable in the long term for most parents. Rocking a tiny baby at 4-5kg is very different from rocking an older baby at 10kg multiple times a day.

Whenever possible, put your baby down sleepy, but awake. Many parents will report their baby only sleeping 45 minutes at a time—well, this is usually the reason. It’s what drives the inability to self-soothe and stitch together cycles.

Now that your baby is over 4 weeks old, we can begin using different techniques to help settle them to sleep. We are not insisting that they self-settle at this age though, as babies up to 12-16 weeks often still need parental reassurance and a lot of hands-on settling.

Remember:cry-it-out is not recommended and should always be avoided. After all, they are still in the midst of the ‘fourth trimester’ until 12 weeks old.

Additional methods of settling - and resettling - babies:

  • Sleep cues like sleepy words
  • Shush-pat technique
  • Capped comforting

1. Introducing sleepy words to your baby:

As part of any routine, even from this early age, both parents should find a phrase or some sleepy words that you can say to your baby as you put them down for sleep. It doesn’t have to be lengthy, but just a few words they will quickly begin to recognize as a sleep cue.

Something like “night night, it’s sleep time now, I love you” or “it’s sleepy time now, sweet dreams.”

Say your sleepy words right as you pop your baby in their bassinet/cot for a sleep and repeat them once or twice before leaving them to fall asleep. If you need to resettle your baby, then repeat your sleepy words during the resettling process.

2. Shush-pat settling technique:

The shush-pat technique is useful for babies up to 4 months.

  1. Make sure the baby is showing tired signs and start the nap time ritual.
  2. Swaddle baby.
  3. Shush baby and rock gently in your arms for a couple of minutes.
  4. Place baby into the bassinet/cot.
  5. Turn baby onto their side, supporting both tummy and back with each of your hands.
  6. Continue shushing. The volume of your voice (or white noise) must match the volume of your baby’s cries if upset.
  7. Gently pat baby in the middle of the back or on their bottom. Keep the patting at the pace of a normal heartbeat (about 60 beats per minute).
  8. As baby is calmed, continue the shush-pat but slow the patting down. Continue shushing or white noise. This can take up to 20 minutes, as this is how long it takes for a baby to fall into a deep sleep state. Sometimes babies will calm but keep their eyes open. Gently stroking their nose in a downwards movement (from forehead to tip of the nose) can encourage them to close their eyes.
  9. DON’T STOP TOO SOON!
  10. Once the baby is asleep, gently roll them onto their back.

3. Capped Comforting:

This is a great technique for younger babies who don’t respond well to the initial hands-on shush-pat settling technique. Every baby has a different temperament, and while some babies LOVE hands-on settling, others are less interested.

Once put to bed, and troubleshooting is complete, give them a short period of time to try and wind down themselves, but if still upset after a few minutes, then enter their room and repeat your sleep words and comfort them as needed with examples below, trying to avoid feeding.

If your baby is well-fed and showing tired signs but struggling to fall asleep, or waking shortly thereafter, begin by troubleshooting simple measures like a nappy change, temperature check, or expelling any remaining burps.

Capped comforting might look something like this:

  • Wrap baby in a muslin wrap with arms (not legs) swaddled firmly.
  • Cuddle for no more than 10 minutes until soothed, put to bed awake and without a pacifier.
  • Leave baby for 5 minutes, even if crying.
  • If awake but not screaming, try having them suck on a clean finger or pacifier.
  • If crying is escalating, pick up and soothe again.
  • Cuddle until no longer screaming, then re-settle and put to bed again.
  • If still awake, use the shush-pat technique to help them off to sleep.

Witching hours is a commonly used, somewhat old fashioned term, used to describe unsettledness in babies from the hours of about 5pm-midnight. Characteristics of witching hours include excessive crying, difficulty to soothe and settle, frequent feeding or refusing to feed, and difficulty sleeping. 

The exact cause of of the unsettled behaviour is unknown, however in my experience the top 3 causes of witching hours include:

1. An overtired baby who hasn't had the appropriate amount of sleep during the day

2. An inadequately winded baby who is suffering from trapped wind or gas

3. A caregiver who is trying to meet competing afternoon/evening demands of the family. ie. prepping and cooking dinner, childcare pick-up for older siblings or pick-up from after school activities, bath and bedtime for older siblings, etc.

Witching hours are not normal and it's our job to try and work out the cause of why your baby is unsettled.

At this young age they are still adjusting to life outside the womb and still very much in the 4th trimester. They can only handle a short period of awake time, and too often the babies that are highly unsettled during the witching hours have been awake for 3 or more hours. This will only exacerbate the unsettledness from overtiredness and overstimulation. 

FAQs

Q1. How to help my baby during witching hours?

ANS: As mentioned above, focus on adequate winding and appropriate daytime sleep. The next best thing to do during witching hours is once they've been fed and burped, use a baby carrier to keep them upright (this can help with trapped wind), close to you, and snug. They're much more likely to sleep in the carrier and it keeps your hands free to continue on with household tasks or dealing with older children. 

Q2. How long do witching hours last for?

ANS: If you see my blog on colic, the period of unsettledness often begins around 2-5 weeks and can last until babies outgrow it around 3-4 months old. Not every baby will experience this and not all will show symptoms for this long though. 

Q3. Can witching hours affect bottle fed and breastfed babies?

ANS: Yes! Bottle fed babies can also show unsettled behaviour during witching hours. This can be due to the same causes as a breastfed (or expressed breastmilk fed) baby, however another possible cause may be that the formula is difficult to digest or causing gut discomfort for your baby. The difference here is that you can be more certain of the volumes of milk your baby is taking, as opposed to breastfeeding where volumes aren't exactly certain.ie. I know you had 150ml of expressed milk 1 hour ago so you can't be hungry, what else could be causing your crying?

Q4. My baby is unsettled both day and night and despite doing what you recommend it's not helping things. What do I do?

ANS: If your parental intuition is telling you something isn't right or you're concerned about your baby's behaviour then I encourage you to see your GP or paediatrician to rule out any underlying medical issues.

Pacifiers or dummies are a very useful settling tool for newborns.

First: If your baby enjoys sucking on a dummy or a thumb, it's completely normal. Up to 90% of infants find it incredibly settling. Babies are born with an innate sucking reflex, and allowing them to suck helps activate their calming reflex.

As a paediatrician, people expect me to have a militant view on dummies, but I don't. It's like my general parenting philosophy—it's what works for you and your baby.

Below are some Pros & Cons of dummies.

The only thing I strongly advise is that they are removed or heavily reduced by the age of two to prevent dental problems (see below for details).

PROS of dummies:

  1. Dummies are a great settling tool. For unsettled babies, I highly recommend their use briefly during the winding process if they are squirming and uncomfortable on their backs.
  2. Unlike the thumb, they can be removed (see below).

CONS of dummies:

  1. Sleep disruption for you and your baby: Sometimes pacifiers may help a baby fall asleep, but they can interfere with maintaining sleep. Parents often find themselves up countless times during the night replacing them (a baby won't learn to find it until about 7 months), or the baby frequently catnaps because the pacifier falls out of their mouth. In these circumstances, I recommend ditching it.
  2. Hygiene: Dummies fall on the ground regularly and get grubby fingers on them.
    Note: Lots of parents clean a dummy by sucking on it, but it's best to run it under water as you're often just transferring oral bacteria from your own mouth to your baby.
  3. Safety: Straps that pin them to sleep suits or outfits can be a strangulation risk.
  4. They can act as a crutch: This can prevent the identification of underlying problems and become another reason for overnight waking. If you are using the dummy 100% of the time to settle your baby, we may be missing something that is causing the discomfort.
  5. Both thumb sucking and dummies can be associated with tooth decay.

Thumbs vs. Dummies:

If your child has a strong oral fixation, a dummy may be preferable to a thumb. The main reason a dummy is preferable over thumb sucking is that a dummy can be taken away to stop the habit (you can't hide a thumb in the cupboard!). Research confirms that a child that previously sucked on a dummy is highly unlikely to move to a thumb.

Thumb sucking can be much harder to prevent once the habit is ingrained. It is also less preferable as it can cause:
👍🏻 Sore thumbs
👍🏻 Infections
👍🏻 Calluses on the thumb

TIP: Remove the dummy (and thumb sucking where possible) beyond the age of 2 to minimize dental problems.

Dental problems from excessive sucking of thumbs or dummies can include:
🦷 Excessive overjet
🦷 Buck teeth
🦷 Posterior crossbite

Note: This is not alarmist—there are plenty of perfectly healthy and happy kids who had a dummy and sucked their thumb a bit. But if it’s excessive, you need to be aware of the possible impact.

Ditching the Dummy

When to ditch the pacifier?

As discussed, babies can’t learn to find and replace their pacifier until around 7 months old, so that can mean a lot of broken sleep waiting for your baby to learn this skill. If your baby is under 4-5 months old, I recommend ditching it if it is negatively impacting their sleep.

The good news is that if sleep has been thrown off track, then getting rid of a pacifier can only help things. Yours and your baby’s sleep shouldn’t be impacted too much more than it already is.

How to ditch the dummy:

  • When settling your baby for a nap and at bedtime, watch their awake times and tired signs and be sure to get them into bed within 10 minutes of showing these signs.
  • Timing is important for all sleeps, but especially when ditching the pacifier, as we don’t want to pop baby down too early (not enough sleepiness) or too late (overtiredness).
  • Settle your baby with no dummy—place them in their cot/bassinet using your settling techniques.
  • If your baby is still awake and upset 10 minutes later, then go and help them to sleep with a pat/cuddle/rock/etc.
  • In the first few days, if you need to resettle your baby (e.g., if they wake early from a nap), try your best to help them back to sleep, but offer the dummy only if all else fails. We want to ensure we keep on top of sleep and don’t have a baby that is too overtired.
  • After the first few days, ditch the dummy altogether, as the baby should be getting used to settling without it.
  • If you have successfully ditched the dummy, there is nothing to say you can’t give it back to them if needed when they are older and can learn to find and replace it themselves.

FAQs on Dummies:

Q. Will sucking on a dummy worsen wind problems? Will my baby swallow more air when they use a dummy?
ANS: Sucking on a dummy does not increase aerophagia (swallowing excess air).

Yes, babies cry. 

Yes, you will find that a healthy baby cries.

Yes, it is a form of communication. 

But excessive crying, frequent feeding, unsettled behaviour, short sleeps – these are all caused by something and the key to eradicating this colic is to understand WHY.


There are myriad reasons why babies cry excessively, 

  • from wind to illness, 

  • hunger to eczema, 

  • and everything in between. 

Fascinatingly, parental instinct as to the cause of unsettled behaviour correlates strongly with true causes.

What are some of the common signs of infant colic or purple crying?

  6. Visibly uncomfortable & distressed

  7. Very hard to burp no matter how diligent you are 

  8. Farting A LOT

  1. Some babies have an immature gut that can’t process elements of milk - be it formula or breastmilk 

  2. Some big 2-week-old babies drink the same volume as a 3-month-old, and their little stomachs just can’t process the sheer volume

  3. Some mums have incredibly quick let-downs and babies guzzle down the milk… and gulp more air 

  4. Poor attachment to the breast or bottle can lead to increased air getting in during feeds

Step 1:Burps, burps & more burps - teach everyone in your family the @DrGolly active winding technique (it's in the program). Any time the baby isn't feeding, you can be burping them 

Step 2:Use the active winding technique for 15min after each feeding period

Step 3:Cycling legs to remain calm when lying flat

Step 4:Regular tummy-time to strengthen their neck - the quicker they can crawl/sit-up the easier it will be to burp them & get that trapped wind out

Step 5:If you’re breastfeeding, be aware of your diet - if you’re drinking/eating a lot of cow’s milk, legumes, ruffage, cured meats, fermented products this could upset your baby - remember stuff that makes you gassy will make your baby gassy 

Step 6:If you’re breastfeeding, be aware of caffeine in breast milk as this can cause unsettled behaviour (I hate saying this, because breastfeeding a newborn is one of the most exhausting jobs out there… & mums need their coffee! Absolutely enjoy this ritual but be mindful of consumption - see my blog on this topic for more info).

Step 7:Check for all other causes that could be upsetting your baby e.g. too hot/cold, itchy clothing tag, uncontrolled eczema, overtired, under tired etc etc.

Step 8:Watch for food intolerances - this is not uncommon in breastfed babies, mucus in the poo is a sign your baby is intolerant to something

Step 9:If you have completed steps 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 & 8 and your baby is still uncomfortable/unsettled it may be time to talk to your GP or paediatrician.

  2. Colic mixes won't fix colic, it will simply make your baby easier to burp and expel trapped wind - your family will need to be fastidious about BURPING!

  4. I also can't recommend pharmaceuticals over social media or email - there are lots of colic mixes out there - again you’ll need to see your GP or paediatrician about whether a) your baby needs this & b) which colic mix is the right one for your baby - be sure to discuss possible side effects too

  5. If you’re talking to your GP or paediatrician, be open to the idea that colic may not be the problem that is making your baby unsettled - always describe the symptoms your baby has to your healthcare professional


You need to resolve the cause of the unsettled behaviour before things will get better:

Q: Is it ok to feed/rock/hold my baby to sleep?ANS: In the newborn period, it is absolutely ok to feed, hold, and rock your baby to sleep. This time is so important in establishing breastfeeding and bonding with your new baby to ensure they feel loved and secure. The newborn period is also a time of “survival” in a lot of ways, and you just have to do what you can to get some sleep. I always suggest trying to pop your baby down to sleep while awake or drowsy, but if it doesn’t work, then remember that tomorrow is a new day. Once you get to 3 weeks and beyond, it is best to try to put your baby down ‘sleepy’ but not ‘sleeping’—this will encourage and enable your baby to self-soothe and settle off to sleep alone. At the end of a sleep cycle (i.e., 45 minutes), a baby who was rocked/fed to sleep will wonder where the parent has gone and will struggle to stitch another sleep cycle together. If they settled by themselves in the first place, they are more likely to re-settle for another cycle.

Q: I'm feeling overwhelmed at tackling both day naps and overnight sleep. Is it ok to work on one thing at a time or will this confuse my baby?
ANS: Yes, it's ok to work on one thing at a time! Just do what you can, and often by working on day naps first, for example, overnight sleep improves dramatically as your baby isn't as overtired, and vice versa.

Q: Should I put my baby down for each sleep in their bassinet/cot?
ANS: If you're at home, then it's always good to get into the habit of putting your baby down in their cot or bassinet. However, it's also important to get out of the house for fresh air and social interaction. A good balance is the 80/20 rule—most sleep (80%) occurs in a normal sleep environment (their nursery, daycare, grandparent’s house, etc.), but on-the-go life (20%) is allowed to happen too! If you're wanting to head out and your baby needs a nap, the best naps to offer while out and about are the first nap of the day and the last nap of the day.

Q: I'm finding resettling my baby every day really tiring and stressful, and he/she continues to wake after one sleep cycle. What can I do?
ANS: At this age, it's ok to continue the nap in a pram, carrier, or as a contact nap to help your baby get some more sleep. It's VERY age-appropriate for babies to only be able to do one sleep cycle at this stage and then wake up, and some babies don't learn to link their sleep cycles until 4–5 months old. Be kind to yourself, and if the resettling every day is exhausting, then just try it a couple of times a week. Eventually, your baby will learn to sleep for longer.

Q: It's really hard to put my baby down to sleep in the cot for the last brief nap of the day. What can I do about this?
ANS: This is VERY common, and babies will often fight this nap the older they get (more about this in the Big Baby program). It's fine to offer this brief nap as an assisted one, so that means trying things like holding them, using the carrier, pram, or car seat. Our goal is for them to have a brief nap as per the routine to ensure they aren't going to bed overtired at night.

Chapter Name: 1.9 The Role of Dads and Non-Breastfeeding Parents
Correct Lesson Content:
Q: What do I do if the non-breastfeeding parent is away overnight?

ANS: Breastfeeding mums ask me all the time what they’re meant to do if dad’s not home or away for work—and they need to resettle their baby when trying to establish a new routine. The best thing you can do is put on one of the non-breastfeeding parent’s shirts or jumpers, masking the smell of breastmilk and letting the baby think it’s not mum coming to feed.

Q: What do we do if the non-breastfeeding parent is regularly away from home with a FIFO (fly in, fly out) role, for example?
ANS: When sleep training and introducing a new routine, consistency is always key, but this can be tricky for some families. If the non-breastfeeding parent is away regularly, I still recommend the baby be settled by them as much as possible. In some cases, this would mean the breastfeeding mother does 3 nights a week (masked in their partner’s top—see above) and the non-breastfeeding parent does 4 nights a week. If in a FIFO role, I recommend implementing the routines and new settling techniques in a period when both caregivers are home for a week together, and the non-breastfeeding parent remains the key settler whenever they are home.

Q: What do I do if I’m a single breastfeeding parent? Can the Dr. Golly Sleep Program still work for me?
ANS: The answer is yes. Selecting consistent routines and settling techniques while following the winding and nutrition advice in the program should help you achieve great outcomes—it just might be a bit tougher and take a bit longer to achieve the desired results. If you have signed up for the program because your baby is particularly unsettled, this is a great opportunity to ask for help from loved ones. Exhaustion and stress are two key factors that dramatically reduce milk supply, and hungry babies tend to be very unsettled. Having someone stay with you for a week while you implement a new routine and have them do the overnight settling may be incredibly helpful for both your physical and mental health.

Lesson Name: Pros and Cons: Breast and Bottle
Correct Lesson Content:
After giving birth to your baby there may have been circumstances that required you to feed your baby with a bottle. Your baby may have been premature, making it difficult to feed at the breast, or you may have nipples that were highly sensitive, damaged or shaped in a way that made it difficult for your baby to latch properly. Delayed lactation is another reason many women introduce bottles in the early days. 

Whether you choose to breastfeed or bottle-feed (or a combination of both), the decision is a personal one that is never made lightly. Consideration is always given to ensure baby’s nutritional needs are met and ongoing feeding plans are implemented that support your wishes and capabilities moving forward.



Pros 

Cons

Breastfeeding

  • Ready when your baby is ready. No preparation required

  • Has all the nutrients baby needs

  • Boosts baby’s immune system

  • Protects fragile gut systems 

  • Reduces risk of SIDS

  • Discomfort and challenges in some cases, especially early

  • Supply issues

  • Frequent feeding

Bottle

  • Can feed your baby breastmilk and formula

  • Easy for compromised babies still developing sucking and strength

  • Dad + family + caretaker can feed baby

  • See how much milk baby is drinking

  • Bottle refusal

  • Breast refusal

  • Overfeeding

  • Cleaning and sterilizing

  • Lacks some nutrients

  • Can be inconvenient during night feeds or when out of the home

Best teat shape to choose and which ones to avoid 


While it’s so tempting to go out and buy every type of bottle and every type of teat when trying to get your baby to take a bottle, it’s best to stick to just a couple and avoid overwhelming your baby. 


The best shape of teat have 2 features:


A gradual slope



​A narrow base​





Shapes to avoid include those with abrupt edges or no gradual transition at the base such as the following. ​

​



Which teat flow to choose for which baby 

​

Choosing the right flow rate is incredibly important. 

  • Too slow and your baby will become frustrated. 

  • Too fast (both breast and bottle) and your baby can gulp, splutter, you might see milk spilling from the sides of the mouth, gagging, coughing, and pushing the teat out.


For a newborn:

Some brands prioritise sourcing organic ingredients, others focus on locally-sourcing. Some are cow-milk based, others soy, rice or other animal-based. When you’re breastfeeding, your body needs extra nutrients. That’s because your body is working harder to make breastmilk full of nutrients for your baby.  

Producing breastmilk requires energy. Some women find they need to increase their normal diet by 50% or an extra 400-500 calories per day, to make enough milk to meet their baby’s needs; extra body fat gained during pregnancy is one way of providing mothers with the necessary calories to make this milk. 

For mothers keen to reduce weight after delivery, it’s important to consider a gradual return to pre-birth weight, as any sudden weight loss can result in a dramatic reduction in milk production, associated with the sudden loss of body fat.

The recommendations for daily intake in breastfeeding mothers are:
● vegetables – 7½ serves a day
● fruit – 2 serves a day
● grain foods – 9 serves a day
● protein – 2½ serves a day
● dairy or calcium-enriched products – 2½ serves a day

If you’re eating a healthy and varied diet, you will get enough of most nutrients, but there are a few to be specifically aware of:

Calcium: Calcium makes up an important part of breastmilk and is very important for your baby’s bone development. You get calcium from:
● dairy products like milk, cheese and yoghurt (be aware of possible cow milk intolerance in babies)
● calcium-enriched products, like some brands of soy milk
● fish with edible bones, like sardines and salmon
● tofu
● some green leafy vegetables like kale and bok choy
● white beans, figs, sesame seeds, almonds, broccoli, seaweed


Iodine: Your baby depends on your breast milk as a source of iodine , which keeps the brain and nervous system developing. You get iodine from dairy products, seafood, iodised salt, potatoes, cheese, cranberries, tuna, shellfish and dried prunes. Iodine deficiency in breastfeeding mothers can be a risk for babies. So when you’re breastfeeding, it’s recommended that you take an iodine supplement of 150 micrograms (μg) per day. If you have any pre-existing thyroid problems, check with your doctor before taking a supplement.


Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 is very important for your baby’s developing nervous system. You get vitamin B12 from meat, fish (especially shellfish, tuna), eggs, milk, yoghurt, brewer’s yeast and fortified breakfast cereals. Those on vegetarian/vegan diets or taking antibiotics or anti-inflammatories may have reduced vitamin B12 levels.


Vitamin D: Vitamin D helps your baby absorb calcium, which your baby will need for bone growth and development. Your body makes most of the vitamin D you need from exposure to sunlight. There are also small amounts of Vitamin D in oily fish, fish oils supplements, egg yolks, mushrooms, milk, ricotta cheese and butter. You might be at risk of vitamin D deficiency if you’re dark-skinned, keep all of your skin covered or rarely go outdoors. If you’re deficient, you and your baby might need to take a vitamin D supplement.


Iron:Iron helps the body make haemoglobin, the major part of red blood cells, helping us deliver oxygen around the body. When iron deficient - or anaemic - you may feel lower energy levels. To increase this, eat more brown rice, soybean, oysters, chicken, beef, turkey, lentils, tofu, nuts, seeds and green leafy vegetables. To further maximise your iron absorption, when eating these foods, add some vitamin C (from citrus fruits) and be sure to avoid excess dairy - as this reduces iron absorption.


Zinc: Zinc is a crucial ingredient in our immune system. It can be found in red meat, poultry, beans, nuts, oats, seeds and seafood.


Omega 3 fatty acids: These occur naturally in flax seeds, chia seeds, salmon, walnuts, tofu, oysters, canola oil, brussel sprouts and avocados.


Vegan and vegetarian mothers may experience lower milk supply or fatigue due to reduced B12 intake. Calcium, protein and iron levels may also be reduced. To help the body absorb iron, add foods high in vitamin C such as citrus fruits. For protein, consider plant sources, such as soy products and meat substitutes, legumes, lentils, nuts, seeds, and whole grains. For calcium, include dairy products (unless vegan), dark green vegetables, calcium-enriched and fortified products, such as juices, cereals, soy milk, soy yoghurt and tofu. There is no need to eat against your beliefs, but have your nutrient levels checked and supplement these if any are low - it is not only important for your baby - it’s also crucial for you and your energy levels.


Fluids: Water intake is crucial, and never more so than when breastfeeding. Most mothers will attest to insatiable thirst during the breastfeeding period and this is not surprising - given the water content of breastmilk! The recommended ‘2 litres per day’ is a good starting point, but drink more if you remain thirsty. Be careful not to drink excessive amounts; excessive water intake does not result in more milk production and can worsen oedema (swelling). Avoid soft drinks, fruit juices, flavoured milk, flavoured water, sports drinks and energy drinks too.

Newborn babies are highly sensitive to caffeine. Your newborn baby will take a significant amount of time to process the caffeine that comes through your breastmilk – which can remain in your system for up to 50 hours. The type of effect caffeine can have on babies includes jitteriness, more unsettled behaviour, difficulty sleeping, increased colicky behaviour, and general unhappiness. Be aware that caffeine isn’t just in coffee but also found in tea, chocolate, cola, and energy drinks. The amount of caffeine that transfers into your breastmilk is about 1% of what is consumed and reaches a peak 60 minutes after consumption. It is recommended not to consume more than 200mg of caffeine per day.

Caffeine content in common drinks and food:

Drink/food = Caffeine level (mg)

  • Espresso coffee = 145 mg / 50 mL shot
  • Formulated caffeinated drinks / ‘Energy’ Drinks = up to 80 mg / 250 mL can
  • Instant coffee (1 teaspoon / cup) = 60–80 mg / 250 mL cup
  • Tea = 10–50 mg / 250 mL cup
  • Coca Cola = up to 54 mg / 375 mL cup
  • Milk chocolate = 20 mg / 100 g bar

The amount of alcohol in your blood is the same as the amount of alcohol in your breastmilk.

It is generally safe to enjoy a glass of alcohol but there are a few factors to take into consideration, including your weight, your food intake, alcohol strength, volume consumed and timing of breastfeeds.

Alcohol will appear in your blood 30-60 minutes after you begin drinking, so if you do wish to enjoy an alcoholic drink, it is safest to do it immediately after a feed. The only thing that will reduce the amount of alcohol in your breastmilk is time.

I hear regularly in my consults"I'm worried my baby is allergic to something in my breastmilk."It is extremely important to highlight the difference between allergy and intolerance.

Babies can’t be allergic to their mother’s milk. However, it is possible to be intolerant to something the breastfeeding mother has eaten or drunk, which then passes to the baby via breastmilk. With intolerance, the more exposure, the more symptoms. This is different from an allergy, where even the smallest exposure triggers a reaction.

Note: Intolerances are common in both bottle-fed and breastfed babies.

The more common symptoms of intolerance include:

  • Mucus (in moderate-severe cases, blood) in the stool
  • Irritability
  • Eczema
  • Difficulties with weight gain

Mucus in Poo: 💩

You can see mucus in the poo by its shine—if you hold the nappy together and pull it apart, you'll see strings like power lines. Mucus in the poo is a sign of inflammation.

The most common foods babies can be intolerant to are:

  • Cow’s milk
  • Soy
  • Rice
  • Egg
  • Corn
  • Gluten

What to do if you think your baby is intolerant to something?

  • My first recommendation if you're seeing a lot of mucusy poos is to consider food exclusion.
  • If your baby is bottle-fed, you may want to try a non-cow’s milk-based formula.
  • If you’re breastfeeding, you may want to decrease or avoid cow’s milk products first.

Breastfeeding & exclusion diets:

  • It can take 2-3 days for a food group to leave your system and a few more days to see results in your baby—don't expect immediate changes.
  • If limiting cow’s milk doesn’t help, try eliminating soy next. For most babies, this should solve the issue. If symptoms persist, follow the list above in order.
  • Breastfeeding is one of the hardest jobs out there—this shouldn't be too strict. If your baby has strong weight gain, is settled, and sleeping well, there's no reason to deprive yourself of essential food. Small amounts of mucus can be tolerated.
  • Breastfeeding diets need to stay balanced. If you're removing food groups, talk to your GP about maintaining proper nutrition, as this is crucial for milk supply.
  • Once your baby's stools have been normal for a while, you can slowly reintroduce excluded foods. If your baby remains happy and the stools stay normal, you'll know you're back on track.
  • Depending on severity, you can try reintroducing foods after about a month.

Some notes on intolerances/mucus in poo:

  • Mucus in the poo is a sign of inflammation but is not always a major concern—if your baby has strong weight gain, is settled, and sleeping well, there is no need to panic.
  • If your baby is irritable, has trouble sleeping, or struggles with weight gain, it may be worth investigating further.

Remember: This advice is general. If you are concerned about intolerances, discuss them with your baby’s doctor.

Once a comfortable position has been established and the baby's chest and tummy are touching the mother’s chest and tummy it’s time to attach to the breast. 


Step 1: While holding your baby, look down and make sure your breast falls naturally toward your baby’s mouth without you having to move the breast one way or another. If you have to move your breast then your baby is not in the right position. Usually by moving your baby just a little bit more will enable a successful latch. 


Step 2: Now bring your baby close to the breast, your baby can’t do this alone unless in the laid-back position.  It is important that the baby's neck and shoulders are supported when bringing the baby to the breast.


TIP: You should avoid placing your fingers on the back of the baby’s head, this will interfere with the baby’s ability to extend its neck and tilt its head back which is crucial for effective suck/swallow and milk removal. Imagine having someone press their finger on the back of your head while you’re trying to have a drink. 


Step 3: When the baby’s chin and bottom lip are deeply pressed into the breast tissue and the nipple is aligned just above the baby’s top lip the baby will open wide extending its mouth over the nipple, enabling an effective suck to be established. If you position the nipple too high or too low the baby will not latch successfully.

What is cluster feeding?

Cluster feeding is when your baby’s feeds are very frequent or ‘clustered’ together. 

During these periods, your baby seems to feed almost continuously over several hours, often in the evening or the early hours of the morning, and may not settle to sleep easily. This can be normal in the first four weeks of life (and beyond), as your baby intentionally increases your supply to meet their calorie needs. It can also be associated with low supply or sometimes comfort feeding, masking the true cause of unsettled behaviour.


What are the common cluster feeding ages?

After the newborn phase, cluster feeding can happen:

6-16 week growth spurts: 

  • Normal Cluster feeding can last a few days during growth spurts

  • Take a look at ways to increase your supply during these periods below

4 months: This is a time of rapid development for your baby

  • Big changes like rolling and the associated unswaddling … and a big growth spurt, often requiring more calories 

  • If your baby has become increasingly fussy around this age, see my blog on 4 Month Sleep Regression – Expert tips to help baby sleep for more on this topic

After 6 months: Cluster feeding usually decreases as babies start eating solid foods

  • I like parents to be on the look-out for signs of readiness for solids from 4 months

  • See my blog Baby’s First Foods – Starting Solids & Testing Allergens

Early evening 

  • see my blog on witching hour for more on why this can be a particularly unsettled time for young families.

  • In the setting of an exhausted breastfeeding mother, this can often be the time when your supply is at the lowest of the day.

  • Once you read the witching hour blog, you’ll quickly realise that  if you have a fussy baby in the early evening a baby carrier is going to be your best friend! 


Cluster feeds happen during baby growth spurts

After 4-6 weeks for the next few months, your baby will take a similar volume of breastmilk each day, with occasional growth spurts and increased appetite causing temporary increases in volume. Follow your baby’s lead on these…  and don’t forget…the most important thing to remember during these often exhausting periods is that cluster feeding is temporary. 


How long does cluster feeding last?

Cluster feeding or frequent feeding can go on indefinitely if:

  1. Your supply is not building to match your babies demand for calories, or 

  2. Your baby is comfort feeding to mask another cause of reason driving discomfort 


As a general rule, if cluster feeding is lasting more than a day or two, start to dive into ways you can increase your supply or other reasons that might be causing your baby to be unsettled and feed frequently.


How to stop cluster feeding 

The primary reasons babies cluster feed are:

  1. To increase a mothers’ breast milk supply

  2. To distract themselves from something else driving discomfort 

  3. Comfort feeding


Cluster feeding babies are exhausting, so if you’re looking for a way to stop - that’s a perfectly normal response.

If you are wanting to stop cluster feeding, the key questions to ask yourself before stopping are:

Question 1: Is my baby getting a sufficient volume of milk? If no, then ask yourself: 

  • Have I done everything I can (and want to do) to increase supply? (see more on this in the next chapter on Low Milk Supply)

  • Is it feasible or practical for me to make the correct volume of milk for my baby?

  • Notes below to help guide you through all of these questions

Question 2: What else could be driving discomfort?

  • Your baby may not be hungry but you may be feeding regularly to distract them from something that is upsetting them or making them uncomfortable 

  • It could be as simple as an itchy tag or being too hot, trapped wind… or more complicated like intolerance or eczema, whatever it is it’s important to try and unpack why it might be happening

  • My blog on colic might be helpful

Question 3: Is my baby just using me as a human pacifier? 

  • Sometimes it’s not about volume or discomfort …it’s just about comfort 

  • If you’re happy with this, then play on 

  • If you want to stop comfort feeding (which is probably why you’re reading this section)  then one of the best things you can do is go away for a day and/or night (continue to pump while you’re away to maintain supply). Someone else can feed your baby, depending on the age, limiting the feeds to every 3-4 hours during the day will ensure they get deep full feeds and break the habit of snacking - annoyingly it’s really hard to stop these comfort cluster feeds if you’re around, every hormone/bone in your body will encourage you to feed your baby, it’s an incredible built in protective measure 

  • Again if these aren’t a worry for your family, then they aren’t a worry


So what’s the verdict on cluster feeding from a paediatrician?

Cluster feeding is an extraordinary tool your baby has to help their breastfeeding mother make more milk.  If it’s lasting longer than a couple of days and it’s not something you want, then I urge to investigate further.

Nipple tenderness in the first few days after birth is a common experience for new mothers as they get used to the sensation of a baby sucking at the breast. For some mothers however, continued pain and damage requires further investigation. Working out the cause of your pain will help you to find the right solution. 


Causes may be related to:

  • poor attachment 

  • flat/inverted/short/large nipples 

  • infection e.g. thrush, dermatitis or vasospasm 

  • problems with baby’s suck due to gestation, tongue-tie, high palate, torticollis, facial abnormalities and jaw problemsIncorrect handling and use of breastfeeding equipment such as breast pads, nipple shields and pumps can also contribute to nipple pain and trauma

  • cracked or bleeding nipples can often occur after the baby’s very first breastfeed or in the following hours and days after birth when you and your baby are still learning to breastfeed


Pausing breastfeeding: 

If your baby is unable to latch successfully and the nipple pain is increasing, you may need to consider resting your nipples by taking your baby off the breast for 12-24 hours. Return the baby back to the breast, once the nipples have healed. 

It is extremely important you continue to remove your colostrum/milk every 2-4 hours by hand and/or pump to ensure your milk supply continues to build and you successfully reach your maximum supply at 4-6 weeks.  

Your baby can be given your expressed breastmilk by cup, bottle, spoon, syringe or finger until you can comfortably return your baby back to the breast. Only you will know what method feels right and works best for you and your baby and when the time is right to return your baby back to the breast. 


Treatment: 

Lanolin is a natural treatment that can be applied to the nipples after a feed. Use a small amount and by the time baby feeds it will have soaked into the nipple, so there is no need to wipe it off pre-feed. 

Another great option is to simply hand express a few drops of breastmilk at the end of a feed, rub it on your damaged nipples and let them air dry. Breast milk has lots of healing properties and is the most natural treatment of all.

If you have one of these problems, with good support from the beginning, your baby may be able to latch successfully without causing any damage to the nipple or breast tissue. It is far better to keep your baby calm and relaxed by giving some milk to satisfy their initial hunger, then bring them back to your chest for skin-to-skin and cuddles.

Your key focus at this point is to establish a good milk supply as quickly as possible so you can:

  • Have milk to give your baby and return your baby back to the breast as soon as possible now that the milk volume has increased.
  • Your baby will suck so much better once the milk is flowing.

You may find you need to use a nipple shield initially when returning your baby to the breast until your baby feels comfortable and trusts the breast will deliver the milk volume needed. It’s possible that once your baby is breastfeeding well, you no longer need the nipple shield. This will depend on the degree of your nipple inversion.

If you attempt to remove the shield, make sure you remove it after the baby has had enough milk to feel relaxed and content but still wants to continue feeding. Otherwise, your baby may protest and become angry if the shield is removed too soon and they are unable to latch onto the nipple.

This is likely to occur anytime from 24 hours post-birth when an increase in milk, blood, and lymphatic fluid in the breast causes heavy, swollen breasts that often make attaching the baby to the breast difficult.

While this can be a normal part of the process of breastfeeding, it can lead to:

  • A sudden reduction in milk supply and mastitis if not attended to quickly.
  • A drainage technique called Reverse Pressure Softening can help soften the tissue at the base of the nipple enough to help your baby gain a deeper latch, improving the transfer of milk from breast to baby.

Reverse Pressure Softening:
This is a technique where a small amount of milk is expressed off, either using a pump or by hand, to soften the areola and make it easier for the baby to attach. If your baby is unable to remove the milk effectively, a pump may be required until your baby is ready and able to feed from the breast. Sometimes women get relief from a single pump-out, removing all the milk from their breasts just once. This softens the breasts, making them more comfortable and helping make it easier for the baby to attach and suck at the breast.

Prevention:

  • Correct position/attachment
  • Drain breast before switching sides
  • Unrestricted breastfeeding (or expressing) 8-12 times in 24 hours
  • Avoid skipping night feeds

Management:

  • Avoid hot stimulating showers on breast tissue as this can overstimulate and increase swelling.
  • Use a warm compress on the breast before breastfeeding to assist in the letdown (milk ejection) reflex.
  • Express by hand or pump a small amount of milk before breastfeeding, or use the Reverse Pressure Softening technique to soften the tissue around the base of the nipple before attaching the baby to the breast.
  • If the baby only breastfeeds on one side and the other breast is uncomfortable, express enough milk out of the other side for comfort only.
  • Use cool packs on the breast after a feed to help reduce swelling and discomfort.
  • Talk to your doctor about the use of anti-inflammatories or pain relief if swelling and discomfort continue.
  • Avoid skipping the night feed.

1 in 5 breastfeeding women in Australia will get Mastitis in the first 6 months post birth.

Mastitis is when the breast becomes inflamed because of blocked milk ducts and/or damaged nipples. Breast tenderness, redness, and painful lumps, together with flu-like symptoms such as fevers, shivers, and body aches, are all common symptoms. Mastitis guidelines have recently changed in early 2023; these are outlined below.

Causes:

  • Premature babies – weak suck, short feeds. Milk not removed effectively
  • Large breasts/oversupply – hindmilk left in the breast
  • Poor positioning/attachment – blisters, grazes, and cracked nipples allowing bacteria to enter the breast
  • Engorgement – oedema obstructing milk flow from milk ducts to the nipple
  • Giving formula and using a dummy – delayed drainage causing full breasts & lumpiness
  • Feeding on one breast only per feed – other breast becomes hard and lumpy
  • Skipping night feeds – reduces supply and breasts become hard and lumpy
  • Sudden cessation of breastfeeding – hard, lumpy breasts
  • Tight bra causing pressure on breast tissue – obstruction of flow

Prevention:

  • Drain the breast often, 8-12 times in 24 hours (use a pump if the baby is not able to effectively remove the milk)
  • Avoid skipping the night feed or delaying breastfeeds
  • Offer both breasts if possible, and if the baby is not able to remove milk from the other breast, then use a pump to remove enough milk for comfort and offer the second breast first at the next feed
  • Position and latch correctly
  • Gently stroke the breast towards the nipple before feeding
  • If the breast still feels full after a feed, then express until it feels more comfortable. Be careful not to overexpress, though

Treatment:

  • Rest between feeds
  • Use warmth for a few minutes before breastfeeding to help you relax and stimulate the milk ejection reflex (letdown)
  • Use cool packs intermittently after and between breastfeeds to help soothe painful breasts and reduce inflammation
  • If unresolved and you are feeling unwell after 24 hours and your breasts are red, tender, and becoming lumpy, contact your doctor as you may need antibiotics
  • Anti-inflammatory and pain relief medications can be useful. Speak to your doctor or pharmacist before starting these
  • Keep feeding your baby from the breast if possible, as this is the best way to keep draining the milk and preventing blocked ducts
  • Ultrasound therapy can be effective—usually only 1-2 treatments needed. It can improve inflammation, unblock ducts, and help clear infection by assisting the antibiotics to work more effectively.

For more information, see The Royal Women’s website on Mastitis.

Breastmilk volume continues to increase until your baby reaches 4-6 weeks, at which time it tends to adjust to meet your baby’s needs. Some mothers continue to make more than their baby needs, and this is known as ‘oversupply.’

Effects on Mum:

  • Uncomfortable heavy breasts
  • Rapid refill post feeds
  • Fast letdowns and leaking make it difficult to feed in public
  • Difficulty latching baby

Effects on Baby:

  • Coughing and spluttering as flow is too fast, causing baby to pull off/on
  • Difficulty latching
  • Breast refusal, distressed behavior, crying
  • Short feeds on each breast causing lactose overload
  • Lots of wet and dirty nappies, windy, loose frothy poos
  • Vomits post feed
  • Rapid weight gain

Block feeding to decrease supply:
You can reduce milk production by ‘block feeding,’ which will result in more comfortable breasts and a supply that meets your baby’s needs within days.

Block feeding is done by getting your baby to feed on one breast for a period of 3-4 hours and then repeating on the other breast.

If, during the 3-4 hours, the other breast becomes hard and uncomfortable, removing a small amount of milk for comfort is all that’s needed. You can do this by hand expression or using a pump. If you choose to get your baby to latch and remove the milk, be mindful of the high lactose content in the foremilk, as this could give your baby excessive wind and pain. Keeping your baby on one side helps drain the breast, ensuring the removal of all the rich, creamy hindmilk.

When there is not enough milk in the breasts to meet your baby’s nutritional requirements, it is considered having a‘low milk supply’.In the first few days after birth, it can be normal for women to have a low supply. Most women will go on to develop a full supply to meet their baby’s needs by 4-6 weeks. If production seemed low from the start or suddenly dropped off despite everything going right, it’s worth investigating further to find the answers and explanation for what’s happening. Pinpointing the reasons for a low supply will help target a strategy to make the most milk possible.

Possible causes of low supply:

  • Stress, anxiety, and sleep deprivation
  • Latch problems
  • Weak suck due to prematurity, jaundice
  • Maternal medications
  • Breast surgery, insufficient breast tissue
  • Hormonal issues
  • Mastitis
  • Skipping feeds and offering formula or topping up with formula
  • Natural low supply, not all mothers were built to exclusively breastfeed

How to increase milk supply:

  • Breastfeed and/or pump every 2-3 hours or 8-12 times in 24 hours.
  • Use compression and massage on your breasts during breastfeeding and pumping to help with milk flow and drainage.
  • Try ‘switch feeding’ by offering each breast twice. As soon as you notice your baby slowing down and no longer swallowing frequently, switch to the other breast. Repeat this process twice.
  • If your baby is too sleepy, take them off the breast and use a hospital-grade pump. Express for 5 minutes on the right, then 5 minutes on the left, and repeat this on both breasts. This is effective for premature babies or any baby having difficulty latching in the first few days.
  • Increase your intake of galactagogues (foods, herbs, or medications that increase milk supply) such as whole grains (especially oats), dark leafy greens, fennel, chickpeas, nuts, and seeds (especially almonds).

What to do regarding low supply in the first few days of breastfeeding:

  • If you are unable to express any colostrum and/or breast milk or only getting a few drops, consider whether your baby needs to be supplemented with donor milk or formula.
  • Remember that a well-fed baby will feed better at the breast.
  • Sometimes a delay in lactation or simply having a low supply may require you to give your baby extra fluids (expressed milk or formula) until you can build up your supply to meet their needs. It is important to consider your baby’s nutritional requirements, as the extra calories and fluids provide energy for more effective breastfeeding while also preventing jaundice or excessive weight loss.

There are three basic ingredients for making breast milk:

  • Stimulation: Breastfeeding is driven by supply and demand. The more your baby stimulates your breasts by sucking, the more milk is produced.
  • Sleep: A breastfeeding mother’s need for sleep is more important than ever, as it allows her body to focus on milk production. Many mothers find a much greater supply in the morning after a decent stretch of sleep.
  • Water: Breast milk is predominantly water, so staying hydrated both day and night is essential.

If there are three key ingredients to making milk, there is one guaranteed way to reduce supply:STRESS.Stress and fatigue can have a detrimental effect on milk volume and flow. To help manage stress, consider asking family and friends to assist with errands, housework, and caring for older children so you can rest during the day while your baby sleeps.

If you feel you have a low supply, please discuss this with your health nurse, lactation consultant, or local doctor. Remember, not every mother is destined to exclusively breastfeed. Some may not even be able to breastfeed for the first week. If these techniques don’t improve supply or attachment concerns remain, speak to a lactation consultant, but also consider that mix-feeding might be a suitable alternative.

The stress and sleep deprivation associated with frequent night feeds, some pro-lactation medications, guilt, fear, or perceived judgment can negatively impact a mother’s general health and well-being. Adding formula top-upsdoes NOTundo the benefits of breast milk and breastfeeding. In fact, many mothers who shift to mix-feeding when supply wanes often end up breastfeeding for longer than those who persist under stress.

  • Increase your intake of galactagogues (foods, herbs, or medications that increase milk supply) such as whole grains (especially oats), dark leafy greens, fennel, chickpeas, nuts, and seeds (especially almonds).

What to do regarding low supply in the first few days of breastfeeding:

  • If you are unable to express any colostrum and/or breast milk or only getting a few drops, consider whether your baby needs to be supplemented with donor milk or formula.
  • Remember that a well-fed baby will feed better at the breast.
  • Sometimes a delay in lactation or simply having a low supply may require you to give your baby extra fluids (expressed milk or formula) until you can build up your supply to meet their needs. It is important to consider your baby’s nutritional requirements, as the extra calories and fluids provide energy for more effective breastfeeding while also preventing jaundice or excessive weight loss.

There are three basic ingredients for making breast milk:

  • Stimulation: Breastfeeding is driven by supply and demand. The more your baby stimulates your breasts by sucking, the more milk is produced.
  • Sleep: A breastfeeding mother’s need for sleep is more important than ever, as it allows her body to focus on milk production. Many mothers find a much greater supply in the morning after a decent stretch of sleep.
  • Water: Breast milk is predominantly water, so staying hydrated both day and night is essential.

If there are three key ingredients to making milk, there is one guaranteed way to reduce supply: STRESS. Stress and fatigue can have a detrimental effect on milk volume and flow. To help manage stress, consider asking family and friends to assist with errands, housework, and caring for older children so you can rest during the day while your baby sleeps.

If you feel you have a low supply, please discuss this with your health nurse, lactation consultant, or local doctor. Remember, not every mother is destined to exclusively breastfeed. Some may not even be able to breastfeed for the first week. If these techniques don’t improve supply or attachment concerns remain, speak to a lactation consultant, but also consider that mix-feeding might be a suitable alternative.

The stress and sleep deprivation associated with frequent night feeds, some pro-lactation medications, guilt, fear, or perceived judgment can negatively impact a mother’s general health and well-being. Adding formula top-ups does NOT undo the benefits of breast milk and breastfeeding. In fact, many mothers who shift to mix-feeding when supply wanes often end up breastfeeding for longer than those who persist under stress.

When your newborn baby is placed in your arms for the first time, you hope that your baby will be able to successfully breastfeed, but the reality is that not all newborns will be able to achieve this. If direct breastfeeding is not possible, expressing your breasts is the next best option.

Expressing & Colostrum:
In the first 24-48 hours, the first milk produced is called colostrum, a rich, sticky milk that’s full of goodness designed to protect your baby. Colostrum is generally all your baby needs until your milk comes in, which usually happens around day 2-3. Because of its thick consistency, hand expressing is the best method for removal, as your fingers can press deep enough into the breast tissue to drain the colostrum forward toward the nipple, where it can be easily removed. During this time, it is also vital that the breasts are stimulated regularly (8+ times a day) with a hospital-grade pump.

Expressing & Establishing Milk Supply:
Early stimulation is the most effective way to establish a milk supply that meets your baby’s needs and provides the foundation for long-term milk production and continued breastfeeding. Once your milk has come in, and your baby is still unable to breastfeed, continue to express to feed your baby your breastmilk. Combining hand expressing with pumping has been shown to yield more milk. Double pumping (both breasts at the same time) will speed things up, removing the milk in half the time and helping to increase your supply if you are struggling with low supply. Remember to drop back to single pumping and remove just enough for comfort from the second breast if you suddenly find you are developing an oversupply.

Frequency:
Expressing 8-12 times in 24 hours is the recommended frequency to establish a milk supply that will meet your baby’s needs for the long term. Each pump session should only take approximately 10-15 minutes or until your milk flow reduces to drops. A hospital-grade pump will ensure you can remove the milk efficiently and comfortably and is more practical if you are pumping more than 3 times a day.

By week 4, babies are becoming increasingly sensitive. You could take a 1-week-old to a music concert, and they would sleep through it, but by three weeks and beyond, they are more sensitive to stimuli from the external world, as well as the internal world (inside their bodies). This is why colic often starts at this age—babies can no longer ‘tolerate’ whatever is causing discomfort. This is a normal part of their development, but it can still be frustrating when your previously sound sleeper now wakes more frequently, often after just one sleep cycle (40-45 minutes).

Linking sleep cycles and sleeping for 1-2 hours or more independently is a learned skill, and some babies don’t master this until closer to 4-5 months. The best way to encourage your baby to link their sleep cycles is by following a program to create healthy sleep habits early. This includes setting up an ideal sleep environment, watching their awake times and tired signs, and establishing a rhythm for your baby’s day.

This increased sensitivity also comes with increased awareness, so you may notice your baby trying to track you with their eyes. Move close to your baby’s face, interact with them, sing, talk, smile, and give kisses. While they may not respond much until around 6 weeks, they will still enjoy this early form of play, which is an important step in their language, social, and communication development.

It’s also important to note that for some babies, catnapping at this age is developmentally normal. If resettling your baby after a short nap is too stressful and exhausting (let’s be honest—it can be utterly exhausting!), try resettling them 1-2 times a day but don’t stress about it for every nap. If they only take a short nap, you may need to bring their next awake time forward slightly to compensate. When resettling feels overwhelming, consider using a pram, baby carrier, or car seat to extend their nap.

Remember that short naps happen sometimes, and tomorrow is a new day!

By 4 weeks, babies will also have improved head control, so it’s good to encourage tummy time when possible (and when tolerated). As they master tummy time, they will begin to explore rolling. Most babies roll from front to back around 5 months once their arm muscles have strengthened. Rolling from back to front typically happens 1-2 months later. However, every baby is different—some start rolling as early as 4 months, while others skip this step entirely and go straight to unsupported sitting and crawling.

By 3-4 months, your baby is not only growing rapidly but also becoming far more active. While they may not move very far yet, they explore movement by throwing their limbs around. Try lying on the floor and moving all four limbs for 30 seconds—it’s quite a workout, like doing star-jumps or burpees!

This extra movement burns more calories and requires more milk as fuel.

Lesson Name: A Note on the Wonder Weeks
Correct Lesson Content:
Many parents will have heard of the publication, The Wonder Weeks. This English version of a Dutch book released in 1992 draws on data dating back to Jane Goodall’s experience observing chimpanzees in the 1970s. It was written by a psychologist and ethologist (someone who studies animal behaviors) and describes 10 predictable developmental ‘leaps’ that coincide with unsettled behavior and sleep regression. This provides solace to parents who are trying to understand why their child is unsettled and gives them permission to ‘ride it out’ until the leap is finished.

Sounds lovely. Unfortunately, it’s completely false.

Child development is a fluid process—it occurs on a continuum at different times and at different velocities for every child. There are countless variables and influences that alter the rate of child development, so forcing this complex, astonishing process into ten conveniently discreet packages is simply misleading.

You would never state that a baby learns to sit independently the day they turn 6 months old. This milestone can occur at 5 months or just as easily at 8 months, and sitting is a relatively straightforward gross motor development! So how can you predict complex neurological breakthroughs in a newborn?

Moreover, I find it potentially dangerous. I would never want a parent to dismiss unsettled behavior as ‘just another leap, because my app said so’ while potentially missing a treatable cause for poor feeding or reduced sleep.

The Wonder Weeks has been discredited by more recent studies conducted by pediatricians and behavioral psychologists.

There are some positives about the program, particularly in how it encourages parents to interact with their babies and support their development. However, simply playing with your child will achieve the exact same thing—without the erroneous parental pressure or unnecessary guilt if they don’t follow a prescribed developmental timeline.

Development happens through play and interaction.

You don’t need to research every milestone or try to force the next step.

We don’t like to see white/pale stools, black (once the first stool of meconium has passed) or red; these babies need to see a doctor. Many parents have concerns regarding the frequency of their child’s bowel actions and worry their child might be constipated. When thinking of constipation, look at the consistency of the bowel action, not the frequency with which it is passed. Some babies will poo with every feed, others may only poo once a week. As long as the stool is soft and easily passed, you shouldn’t worry about how frequently the baby is pooing. Breastfed babies are almost never constipated.

Tummy time is wonderful for promoting development, interacting with your baby, and enjoying some time without a focus on feeding or winding. Some babies, however, strongly dislike lying on their stomachs, and if this is the case with your baby, don’t feel the need to force it. Plenty of babies have very minimal time spent on their stomachs and still develop perfectly normally.

For babies who dislike tummy time, it’s worthwhile revisiting it every few weeks, as they tend to tolerate it better as they get older.

The History of Tummy Time:

Historically, SIDS rates were disturbingly high. When the American Academy of Pediatrics launched their Back-to-Sleep campaign in 1994, there was a phenomenal 50% reduction in SIDS episodes. While this was undoubtedly successful and should never be challenged, placing children on their backs resulted in some unwanted side effects.

The first was flat-head syndrome (discussed later), and the next was delayed gross motor development. Babies spent less time on their stomachs, pushing up, strengthening their back, shoulder, and neck muscles, which delayed the strength and coordination required for sitting, standing, etc.

Importantly, though, researchers who conducted the 1998 study found that back-sleepers eventually developed their motor skills just fine:

“All infants achieved all milestones within the accepted normal age range,” they wrote.

Another study published that same year reached a similar conclusion—that although babies who spent less time on their tummies developed motor skills more slowly, the discrepancies didn’t last.

And in a 2008 study, researchers reported that babies who were given more awake tummy timerolled and crawled earlier than babies who were given less, but they didn’t learn to sit or walk any sooner.

Interestingly, researchers have also found ties between when babies develop gross motor skills and when they develop certain cognitive skills—which raises questions over whether tummy time might also make kids ‘smarter.’

Studies have found that infants who are able to sit up have a more advanced understanding of the three-dimensional nature of objects, perhaps because they can more easily explore and inspect their toys.

Babies who have spent more time crawling and walking, regardless of their age, also have better spatial memory skills. And a 2014 study found that babies often learn to walk right before they develop language skills—so if they learn to walk later, they might talk later too.

So, yes: Tummy time is good — but you don’t need to overly fret about it. And keep in mind that just a minute or two — even just 30 seconds — of tummy time will add up if you do it regularly.

If your baby really hates it, try placing them on their tummy on your chest instead of on the floor.

By the time your child is enjoying solids, they will have adequate head control but may still be developing trunk strength and co-ordination. It’s important to continue offering tummy time during this time. Tummy time is wonderful for promoting development, interacting with your baby and enjoying some time without a focus on feeding or winding. But some babies strongly dislike lying on their stomachs and if this is the case with your baby, don’t feel the need to force it. Plenty of babies have very minimal time spent on their stomachs and they go on to develop perfectly normally.For babies who dislike tummy time, it’s worthwhile revisiting it every few weeks, because they tolerate it better as they get older.

These measurements will be recorded on your baby’s physical and/or digital records. Your baby’s growth is a good indicator of their overall health, nutrition and development.

Like us, babies come in all shapes and sizes. Centile charts work simply by comparing your baby’s growth with other babies of the same age – the charts differ by gender (different charts exist for certain medical conditions too).

Baby centile and infant growth charts are usually calculated using the World Health Organization’s growth standards.

You will see the percentile lines on the chart running parallel to each other. The percentile lines include 5%, 10%, 25%, 50%, 75%, 90%, and 95%.

Example 1:
If a child’s weight is at the 50th percentile line, that means that out of 100 children of that age, 50 will be bigger than they are, and 50 smaller.

Example 2:
If a child’s weight is in the 75th percentile, that means that your baby is bigger than 75 children and smaller than 25, compared with 100 children their own age.

Example 3:
A baby on the 5th percentile weighs less than 95% of other babies of that age.

When it comes to measuring our babies on these curves, it’s important to remember some babies will always be small, and others will always be large.

You haven’t mastered parenting if your baby is in the 90th percentile, and you’re not a failure if your baby is in the 10th percentile! Where they sit is less important than their rate of growth.

All babies grow at different rates, and ‘normal’ growth varies. 

​

The thing your health care professional will be looking for is that your baby continues to grow at a similar rate – this is often referred to as ‘following the curve’. 

BUT... their growth won’t always follow a smooth linear path on these curves, so be sure to put the growth charts and centiles into context. 

Babies and infants will often bounce up and down slightly on the growth charts, depending on:

  • feeding issues, 
  • illnesses and
  • growth spurts
Don’t obsess about every movement on your baby’s growth chart.
