Lesson Name: Dropping Centiles in the First Months of Life
Correct Lesson Content:
I often encounter 2–3-month-olds referred for concerns regarding faltering weight. While weight reduction requires medical attention, a more common scenario arises where a baby’s weight is increasing in a beautiful way, but their centiles are dropping.

Now before we continue, there is a caveat: weight stagnation, weight loss, or centile dropping in a baby, especially in the setting of:

  • poor feeding,
  • development concerns,
  • low tone, or
  • any other sign or symptom,

Always needs full investigation.

But… often a scenario emerges.

A baby looks to be thriving and has a perfect examination, there’s:

  1. Adequate milk supply,
  2. All investigations for growth failure come up normal,
  3. There are no major concerns from the parents,

...just a baby gaining weight but dropping from, say, the 80th centile to the 50th.

This could be a weight correction, which is when a baby is born at a higher centile than they are genetically likely to remain at, so the loss in centiles is simply a ‘correction’ driven by genetics.




There are a few things we need to consider when discussing the possibility of a weight correction.

To fully understand this concept, let’s go back to the womb. During gestation, the size of the baby is determined by many factors, including:

  • The health of the placenta
  • The umbilical cord
  • The possibility of gestational diabetes
  • Gestation length
  • Maternal blood pressure

Once the baby is born, assuming we’re talking about a well baby who is feeding and growing happily at home with an adequate milk supply, their weight is determined more by their:

  1. Feeding patterns
  2. Genetics

Take, for example, a baby born to two parents who themselves sit low on weight centiles, yet with a mother affected by gestational diabetes who delivers a baby on the 90th centile. This baby is highly unlikely to live on the 90th centile for life. If they were genetically predetermined to be closer to the 15th centile, for example, they will grow and thrive but will steadily drop down the centiles (always growing in weight but dropping in centiles) until they reach the 15th centile.

This commonly occurs in the first few months of life and can explain the drop in centiles, despite the presence of a perfectly happy, healthy baby. It is crucial to remember that any drop in centiles needs to be monitored closely and the threshold for referral should remain low. But once more concerning problems have been comfortably excluded, we can rest assured that this baby is still thriving while simply finding their place on the centiles chart.

Many parents get distressed when their baby brings up milk, but not every spill of milk is a true vomit, and not all refluxed milk means your baby has reflux. In this section, I'll talk you through the different types of vomit and spills and walk through the difference between refluxed milk and a reflux diagnosis.

Reflux exists, but not as commonly as most people think.

Before you continue reading, I want everyone to approach the topics of reflux, reflux diagnosis, and reflux and sleep with caution.

A reflux diagnosis in babies is a serious condition that needs to be treated.

We’ll discuss in this article what I believe to be a widespread misunderstanding of the condition of reflux, an over-diagnosis, and, in my opinion, an over-medication of the condition.

Infant reflux has wrongly become the go-to, rapid explainer of unsettled behaviour in babies.

A true diagnosis of gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD) or gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), depending on where you are, is not particularly common. There’s some terrible language we use around babies and newborns that adds to this confusion and leads to overdiagnosis and overmedication.

The difference between “refluxed milk” and a diagnosis of “gastro-oesophageal reflux disease” (GORD)

Many people incorrectly refer to small amounts of “refluxed milk” or “spills,” “up chucks,” or “possets” of milk as a reflux diagnosis or signs of reflux in babies.

Small spills or possets of milk by a happy, growing baby are completely normal. They don’t cause unsettledness and don’t require specific investigation or management.

Nearly all babies will posset milk from time to time. Some healthy babies posset LOTS of milk – you’ll identify their parents with a cloth over their shoulder or milk down the front of their shirts. These babies are gaining weight and are settled – often referred to as “happy spitters.”

Why babies ‘reflux’ milk

When a baby feeds, the stomach becomes over-stretched, especially if it is full of milk and wind. Any muscle in the body desires to return to its original size, rebounding much like an untied balloon deflates rapidly when released.

In babies who reflux a significant amount of milk, the lower esophageal sphincter muscle is often not fully developed and allows stomach contents to rise back up the esophagus.

This can result in a column of milk rising up the oesophagus (feeding tube) and spilling out, causing your baby to spit up or “reflux” milk.

TIP: By deflating the stomach with more winding, we can reduce the chance of that rising column of milk.

There are generally four types of ‘vomit’ that need to be defined:

  1. Posset: A small volume, effortless ejection of milk. This occurs in almost half of all babies, usually before 2 months of age, peaking at 4 months. These babies, known as “happy spitters,” do not require treatment.

  2. Vomit: An ejection of stomach contents involving retching/gagging. This empties the stomach, and the lost milk needs to be replaced. Large but infrequent vomits are not problematic, but recurrent vomiting needs investigation.

  3. Projectile vomit: This occurs when the stomach is obstructed, often due to pyloric stenosis. It is dramatic (hitting the ceiling or wall) and requires urgent medical attention. Bright green vomit is also a medical emergency.

  4. True reflux (GORD): This is an uncommon condition where frequent milk reflux leads to feed refusal, poor growth, bloody vomits, irritability, and chronic cough. This requires medical evaluation.

The terms “refluxed milk” and a diagnosis of “gastro-oesophageal reflux disease” (GORD) are used interchangeably, and they shouldn’t be.

Your baby’s reflux may not need any treatment at all. It is important not to medicate a baby for “gastroesophageal reflux disease” (GERD) if it is not the cause of their unsettled behaviour.

A 2006 study led by Australian paediatricians showed no link between these milk “spills” or “possets” and symptoms like crying time or back-arching.

“Reflux” has become the rapid explainer for unsettled behaviour, becoming synonymous with colic, but it shouldn’t be.

Colic affects up to 20% of babies, but it is a descriptive term, not a diagnosis.

From 2000-2003, there was a 400% increase in the prescribing of anti-reflux medication, yet no reduction in the incidence of colic – which speaks volumes about the true incidence of reflux.

This is dangerous for two reasons:

  1. The medication prescribed for reflux has side effects.
  2. The true cause of the baby’s unsettled behaviour is being missed.

True gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD) has very serious symptoms:

  • Weight loss
  • Severe feeding difficulties
  • Bloody vomit
  • Bile (green or yellow fluid) in vomit
  • Chronic cough, wheeze
  • Aspiration
  • Haematemesis

Babies with these symptoms may need medication or even surgery – it’s a rare but serious diagnosis.

Incorrect diagnoses of reflux lead to unnecessary medications and an undesirable spiral of ‘medicalisation’ which we need to avoid.

Anti-reflux medications have risks, including respiratory and gastrointestinal infections as well as poor bone health.

A 2006 study (Heine et al, J Paed Child Health 2006) showed no link between ‘spills’ and crying time or back arching. The two most commonly prescribed medicines (H2 receptor antagonists and proton pump inhibitors) had no effect when compared with a placebo.

Please resist the urge to blame reflux for your baby’s unsettled behaviour. Treatments can be harmful and often worsen colic.

Silent reflux is a myth.

Many people refer to spillage or possets of milk as reflux. But even worse is the term “silent reflux” – which is a massive myth!

Some believe an unsettled baby who does not vomit may suffer from “silent reflux,” but this is not a medical diagnosis. There is no scientific evidence to support this in paediatrics.

Misdiagnosing silent reflux is dangerous because it leads to unnecessary medication and ignores the true cause of discomfort.

Are there medications to treat Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD)?

Not all babies who reflux milk need medication, but those diagnosed with GERD might.

If your baby needs treatment, work closely with a paediatrician or paediatric GI specialist to find the right medication and dosage. If you are not seeing improvement, stay in contact with your doctor, as finding the correct medication can take time.

Anti-reflux medications have risks & side effects.

From 2000-2003, there was a 400% increase in anti-reflux medication prescriptions, yet no reduction in colic.

These medications have long-term side effects, including:

  • Increased risk of respiratory and gastrointestinal infections
  • Poor bone health

The two most commonly prescribed medicines (H2 receptor antagonists and proton pump inhibitors) had no effect when compared with a placebo.

Please resist the urge to blame reflux for your baby’s unsettled behaviour. Treatments can be harmful and often worsen colic.

FAQ: My GP or Paediatrician has prescribed reflux medication, and now I’m questioning whether my baby should be taking it?

Before making any changes, talk to your GP or paediatrician to assess your baby for true GORD symptoms.

The advice in blogs is general, and every baby needs individualised care. Many unsettled babies are uncomfortable due to trapped wind, which is often overlooked.

Stopping reflux medication will not alleviate symptoms if the cause was misdiagnosed. Work with your healthcare provider to determine the actual cause of discomfort.
